questions.q: What is the main goal of CPU scheduling?
questions.ex: CPU scheduling aims to maximize CPU utilization and throughput.

questions.q: In priority scheduling, a lower number means:
questions.ex: Lower numerical values indicate higher priority.

questions.q: A scheduling algorithm that allows interruption is called:
questions.ex: Preemptive algorithms allow tasks to be interrupted.

questions.q: What causes starvation in priority scheduling?
questions.ex: If high-priority tasks keep arriving, low-priority ones may never execute.

questions.q: Aging in priority scheduling is used to:
questions.ex: Aging gradually increases the priority of waiting tasks.

questions.q: Which algorithm is used in most modern operating systems for multitasking?
questions.ex: Multilevel queue scheduling is used for handling different process types.

questions.q: Which is not a non-preemptive scheduling algorithm?
questions.ex: Round Robin is a preemptive scheduling algorithm.

questions.q: Which of the following considers priority and arrival time?
questions.ex: Multilevel queues manage based on priority and arrival timing.

questions.q: Which algorithm is best for minimizing average waiting time?
questions.ex: SJF provides the lowest average waiting time under ideal conditions.

questions.q: Which algorithm works best when process lengths are similar?
questions.ex: Round Robin is more efficient when all processes take similar time.

questions.q: Which algorithm uses multiple queues for different job types?
questions.ex: Multilevel queue scheduling separates jobs by type and priority.

questions.q: The term 'context switch' is associated with:
questions.ex: Context switch involves saving and restoring process state.

questions.q: Which of these algorithms is suitable for real-time systems?
questions.ex: Earliest Deadline First is designed for real-time scheduling.

questions.q: In multilevel feedback queue scheduling:
options: All processes start in the same queue
questions.ex: Processes can move to higher or lower priority queues.

questions.q: Which algorithm favors shorter burst time but allows longer ones to execute eventually?
questions.ex: MLFQ favors short jobs but includes aging to avoid starvation.

questions.q: Which of these is NOT a CPU scheduling criterion?
questions.ex: Disk speed is related to I/O, not CPU scheduling.

questions.q: Turnaround time equals:
questions.ex: Turnaround time is the total time from arrival to completion.

questions.q: In which case does Round Robin perform poorly?
questions.ex: A very short time quantum increases overhead due to context switching.

questions.q: What is the time complexity of accessing an element in an array by index?
questions.ex: Array elements can be accessed directly using their index in constant time O(1).

questions.q: In most programming languages, array indexing starts from:
questions.ex: Most modern programming languages like C, Java, Python use 0-based indexing.

questions.q: What is the maximum number of elements that can be stored in an array of size n?
questions.ex: An array of size n can store exactly n elements, indexed from 0 to n-1.

questions.q: Which operation is NOT efficient on arrays?
questions.ex: Insertion at the beginning requires shifting all existing elements, making it O(n).

questions.q: What is the space complexity of an array storing n integers?
questions.ex: An array storing n elements requires O(n) space proportional to the number of elements.

questions.q: In a 2D array arr[3][4], what is the total number of elements?
questions.ex: A 2D array with dimensions 3×4 contains 3 × 4 = 12 elements total.

questions.q: What happens when you try to access an array element beyond its bounds?
questions.ex: Accessing out-of-bounds elements causes undefined behavior in C/C++ or exceptions in Java/Python.

questions.q: Which string operation has O(n) time complexity?
questions.ex: String concatenation typically requires O(n) time to copy characters to a new string.

questions.q: In string matching, what is the time complexity of naive pattern searching?
questions.ex: Naive pattern searching compares pattern of length m with each position in text of length n, giving O(nm).

questions.q: What is the difference between mutable and immutable strings?
options: Mutable can be changed, immutable cannot
questions.ex: Mutable strings can be modified after creation, while immutable strings create new objects for changes.

questions.q: Which data structure is best for implementing a dynamic array?
questions.ex: Vector (C++) or ArrayList (Java) provide dynamic resizing capabilities for arrays.

questions.q: What is the time complexity of finding the length of a null-terminated string?
questions.ex: Finding length requires traversing the entire string until null terminator, taking O(n) time.

questions.q: In row-major order, how are 2D array elements stored in memory?
questions.ex: Row-major order stores elements row by row in contiguous memory locations.

questions.q: What is the maximum number of comparisons needed for linear search in an array of n elements?
questions.ex: In worst case, linear search may need to check all n elements before finding the target.

questions.q: Which algorithm is used for efficient string pattern matching?
questions.ex: Knuth-Morris-Pratt (KMP) algorithm provides efficient O(n+m) string pattern matching.

questions.q: What is a jagged array?
options: 2D array with rows of different lengths
questions.ex: Jagged arrays are 2D arrays where each row can have a different number of columns.

questions.q: In C/C++, what character marks the end of a string?
questions.ex: C-style strings are null-terminated, ending with the null character \0.

questions.q: What is the time complexity of reversing an array in-place?
questions.ex: Reversing requires swapping elements from both ends, visiting each element once: O(n).

questions.q: Which operation is most efficient on a sorted array?
questions.ex: Binary search on sorted arrays has O(log n) complexity, much better than O(n) linear search.

questions.q: What is string interpolation?
questions.ex: String interpolation allows embedding variable values directly into string literals.

questions.q: In array rotation, rotating [1,2,3,4,5] left by 2 positions gives:
questions.ex: Left rotation by 2 moves first 2 elements to the end: [1,2,3,4,5] → [3,4,5,1,2].

questions.q: What is the space complexity of merge sort for arrays?
questions.ex: Merge sort requires O(n) auxiliary space for the temporary arrays during merging.

questions.q: Which string comparison method is case-insensitive?
questions.ex: strcasecmp() performs case-insensitive string comparison in C.

questions.q: What is the advantage of using StringBuilder over String concatenation?
questions.ex: StringBuilder avoids creating multiple intermediate string objects, making it faster for multiple concatenations.

questions.q: In dynamic arrays, what happens when capacity is exceeded?
questions.ex: Dynamic arrays automatically resize (usually doubling capacity) when more space is needed.

questions.q: What is the time complexity of checking if two strings are anagrams?
questions.ex: One approach is to sort both strings and compare, which takes O(n log n) time.

questions.q: Which array traversal visits elements in reverse order?
questions.ex: Backward traversal starts from the last index and moves toward the first index.

questions.q: What is a palindrome string?
options: String that reads same forwards and backwards
questions.ex: A palindrome reads the same forwards and backwards, like 'radar' or 'level'.

questions.q: In matrix multiplication, what must be true about dimensions?
options: Columns of first = Rows of second
questions.ex: For A×B multiplication, number of columns in A must equal number of rows in B.

questions.q: What is the Boyer-Moore algorithm used for?
questions.ex: Boyer-Moore is an efficient string searching algorithm that can skip characters during pattern matching.

questions.q: What principle does a stack follow?
questions.ex: Stack follows Last In First Out (LIFO) principle where the last element added is the first to be removed.

questions.q: What principle does a queue follow?
questions.ex: Queue follows First In First Out (FIFO) principle where the first element added is the first to be removed.

questions.q: Which operation adds an element to a stack?
questions.ex: Push operation adds an element to the top of the stack.

questions.q: Which operation removes an element from a queue?
questions.ex: Dequeue operation removes an element from the front of the queue.

questions.q: What happens when you try to pop from an empty stack?
questions.ex: Attempting to pop from an empty stack results in stack underflow condition.

questions.q: What is the time complexity of push and pop operations in a stack?
questions.ex: Both push and pop operations in a stack take constant time O(1).

questions.q: Which data structure is used to implement function calls?
questions.ex: Function call stack uses stack data structure to manage function calls and returns.

questions.q: What is a circular queue?
options: Queue where rear connects to front
questions.ex: Circular queue treats storage as circular, where rear pointer wraps around to connect with front.

questions.q: Which application commonly uses stacks?
questions.ex: Stacks are used for expression evaluation, particularly for handling operator precedence and parentheses.

questions.q: What is a priority queue?
questions.ex: Priority queue serves elements based on their priority rather than insertion order.

questions.q: In postfix expression evaluation, which data structure is used?
questions.ex: Stack is used to evaluate postfix expressions by pushing operands and popping for operations.

questions.q: What is a double-ended queue (deque)?
options: Queue allowing insertion/deletion at both ends
questions.ex: Deque allows insertion and deletion operations at both front and rear ends.

questions.q: Which traversal algorithm uses a queue?
questions.ex: Breadth-First Search (BFS) uses a queue to visit nodes level by level.

questions.q: What is stack overflow?
questions.ex: Stack overflow occurs when trying to push elements beyond the stack's maximum capacity.

questions.q: In infix to postfix conversion, which data structure is used?
questions.ex: Stack is used to handle operators and parentheses during infix to postfix conversion.

questions.q: What is the space complexity of a stack with n elements?
questions.ex: A stack storing n elements requires O(n) space proportional to the number of elements.

questions.q: Which operation checks the top element of a stack without removing it?
questions.ex: Peek or Top operation returns the top element without removing it from the stack.

questions.q: In a queue implementation using arrays, what indicates an empty queue?
questions.ex: When front equals rear, it typically indicates an empty queue in array implementation.

questions.q: What is the main advantage of implementing stack using linked list?
questions.ex: Linked list implementation allows dynamic sizing without predefined capacity limits.

questions.q: Which scenario is best suited for using a queue?
questions.ex: Queues are ideal for process scheduling where first-come-first-served order is maintained.

questions.q: What is the result of the following stack operations: push(1), push(2), pop(), push(3), pop()?
questions.ex: After push(1), push(2), pop() removes 2, push(3), pop() removes 3, leaving only 1 in stack.

questions.q: In a circular queue of size 5, if front=2 and rear=1, how many elements are there?
questions.ex: In circular queue, when rear < front, elements = (size - front + rear + 1) = 5-2+1+1 = 5, but since rear=1 and front=2, there are 4 elements.

questions.q: Which data structure would you use for implementing browser back button?
questions.ex: Stack is perfect for browser history as the most recently visited page should be accessed first (LIFO).

questions.q: What is the time complexity of enqueue and dequeue operations in a queue?
questions.ex: Both enqueue and dequeue operations in a properly implemented queue take constant time O(1).

questions.q: In which order will elements be removed from a stack containing [1,2,3,4] (4 on top)?
questions.ex: Stack follows LIFO, so elements are removed in reverse order of insertion: 4,3,2,1.

questions.q: What is a monotonic stack?
options: Stack with elements in monotonic order
questions.ex: Monotonic stack maintains elements in either increasing or decreasing order.

questions.q: Which application uses queue data structure?
questions.ex: CPU scheduling algorithms like Round Robin use queues to manage process execution order.

questions.q: What happens in queue overflow?
questions.ex: Queue overflow occurs when trying to enqueue elements beyond the queue's maximum capacity.

questions.q: In balanced parentheses checking, which data structure is most suitable?
questions.ex: Stack is ideal for checking balanced parentheses by pushing opening brackets and popping for closing ones.

questions.q: What is the main disadvantage of array-based queue implementation?
questions.ex: Array-based queues have fixed size limitation and may waste space due to false overflow conditions.

questions.q: What is the basic building block of a linked list?
questions.ex: A node is the basic unit containing data and a reference/pointer to the next node.

questions.q: What is the time complexity of inserting an element at the beginning of a singly linked list?
questions.ex: Insertion at the beginning requires only updating the head pointer, taking constant time O(1).

questions.q: What is the time complexity of searching for an element in a linked list?
questions.ex: Searching requires traversing the list from head to find the element, taking O(n) time in worst case.

questions.q: In a singly linked list, each node contains:
questions.ex: Singly linked list nodes contain data and a pointer/reference to the next node.

questions.q: What is the main advantage of linked lists over arrays?
questions.ex: Linked lists can grow or shrink during runtime, providing dynamic memory allocation.

questions.q: What does NULL/None pointer in the last node of a linked list signify?
questions.ex: NULL pointer in the last node indicates the end of the linked list.

questions.q: In a doubly linked list, each node has:
questions.ex: Doubly linked list nodes have two pointers: one to the next node and one to the previous node.

questions.q: What is the time complexity of deleting the last node in a singly linked list?
questions.ex: To delete the last node, we need to traverse to find the second-to-last node, taking O(n) time.

questions.q: Which operation is more efficient in doubly linked list compared to singly linked list?
questions.ex: Deletion of a given node is O(1) in doubly linked list as we can directly access previous node.

questions.q: What is a circular linked list?
options: List where last node points to first
questions.ex: In circular linked list, the last node points back to the first node instead of NULL.

questions.q: How do you detect a cycle in a linked list?
questions.ex: Floyd's cycle detection algorithm (tortoise and hare) uses two pointers moving at different speeds.

questions.q: What is the space complexity of a linked list with n nodes?
questions.ex: Each node requires space for data and pointer(s), so total space is O(n) for n nodes.

questions.q: In which scenario would you prefer linked list over array?
questions.ex: Linked lists are better when frequent insertions and deletions are needed at arbitrary positions.

questions.q: What is the head pointer in a linked list?
questions.ex: Head pointer stores the reference/address of the first node in the linked list.

questions.q: How do you reverse a singly linked list?
questions.ex: Reversing requires three pointers (previous, current, next) to change link directions iteratively.

questions.q: What happens when you try to access a node after the tail in a singly linked list?
questions.ex: Following the next pointer of the tail node leads to NULL, indicating end of list.

questions.q: Which traversal is possible in a singly linked list?
questions.ex: Singly linked lists can only be traversed in forward direction from head to tail.

questions.q: What is the time complexity of finding the middle element of a linked list?
questions.ex: Finding middle requires traversing the list, which takes O(n) time (can be optimized to single pass).

questions.q: In a doubly linked list, what does the previous pointer of the first node point to?
questions.ex: The previous pointer of the first node points to NULL, indicating no previous node exists.

questions.q: What is the main disadvantage of linked lists?
questions.ex: Linked lists require sequential access and don't support random access like arrays.

questions.q: How do you merge two sorted linked lists?
questions.ex: Merging sorted lists uses two pointers to compare elements and build result list in sorted order.

questions.q: What is a self-referential structure?
options: Structure with same data type pointer
questions.ex: Self-referential structure contains a pointer to the same structure type, used in linked lists.

questions.q: Which memory allocation is used for linked list nodes?
questions.ex: Linked list nodes are typically allocated dynamically using malloc/new during runtime.

questions.q: What is the time complexity of inserting at a specific position in a linked list?
questions.ex: To insert at position k, we need to traverse k nodes first, making it O(n) operation.

questions.q: How do you find the nth node from the end in a linked list?
questions.ex: Two-pointer technique: move first pointer n steps ahead, then move both until first reaches end.

questions.q: What is the advantage of circular linked list over singly linked list?
questions.ex: Circular linked lists allow traversal of entire list starting from any node.

questions.q: In linked list implementation of stack, where do push and pop operations occur?
questions.ex: Stack operations using linked list are performed at the head for O(1) time complexity.

questions.q: What is memory fragmentation in context of linked lists?
questions.ex: Memory fragmentation occurs when linked list nodes are scattered in memory, affecting cache performance.

questions.q: How do you remove duplicates from an unsorted linked list?
questions.ex: Hash table can track seen elements while traversing, allowing O(n) duplicate removal.

questions.q: What is the Floyd's cycle detection algorithm also known as?
questions.ex: Floyd's algorithm is called 'Tortoise and Hare' due to slow and fast pointer movement analogy.

questions.q: What is the maximum number of children a node can have in a binary tree?
questions.ex: Binary trees are defined as trees where each node has at most 2 children (left and right).

questions.q: What is the height of a tree with only one node (root)?
questions.ex: Height is defined as the number of edges from root to deepest leaf. Single node has height 0.

questions.q: In a Binary Search Tree (BST), the left subtree contains values:
questions.ex: BST property: left subtree contains values less than root, right subtree contains greater values.

questions.q: What is the time complexity of searching in a balanced BST?
questions.ex: Balanced BST allows binary search approach, eliminating half the nodes at each step: O(log n).

questions.q: Which traversal visits nodes in the order: Left, Root, Right?
questions.ex: Inorder traversal visits left subtree, then root, then right subtree.

questions.q: What data structure is used for Level Order traversal of a tree?
questions.ex: Level order traversal uses queue to visit nodes level by level (BFS approach).

questions.q: In a complete binary tree with n nodes, what is the height?
questions.ex: Complete binary tree height is ⌈log₂(n+1)⌉ - 1, where ⌈⌉ is ceiling function.

questions.q: What is a leaf node in a tree?
questions.ex: Leaf nodes are terminal nodes that have no children (degree = 0).

questions.q: Which graph representation is better for dense graphs?
questions.ex: Adjacency matrix is more space-efficient for dense graphs with many edges.

questions.q: What is the space complexity of DFS traversal?
questions.ex: DFS uses stack (recursion or explicit) that can go as deep as V vertices in worst case.

questions.q: In which tree traversal do we get sorted order for a BST?
questions.ex: Inorder traversal of BST visits nodes in ascending sorted order due to BST property.

questions.q: What is a strongly connected graph?
options: Directed graph where every vertex is reachable from every other
questions.ex: Strongly connected directed graph has a directed path between every pair of vertices.

questions.q: What is the minimum number of edges in a connected graph with V vertices?
questions.ex: A tree is the minimum connected graph, requiring exactly V-1 edges for V vertices.

questions.q: Which algorithm is used to find shortest path in unweighted graphs?

questions.q: What is a spanning tree of a graph?

questions.q: What is the time complexity of BFS traversal?

questions.q: In a min-heap, the smallest element is located at:

questions.q: What is a bipartite graph?

Graph with two types of edges

questions.q: In a Red-Black tree, what colors can nodes have?

questions.q: What is the time complexity of binary search?

questions.q: In linear search, what is the best case time complexity?

questions.q: What is the average case time complexity of linear search?

questions.q: In binary search, what is the initial value of 'high' pointer for array of size n?

questions.q: What is the space complexity of recursive binary search?

questions.q: Linear search is also known as:

questions.q: When is linear search preferred over binary search?
questions.ex: Linear search is preferred for small arrays or when array is unsorted and sorting cost is high.

questions.q: What is the maximum number of elements that can be eliminated in one comparison in binary search?
questions.ex: Binary search eliminates approximately half of the remaining elements in each comparison.

questions.q: Which search is more suitable for linked lists?

questions.q: What is interpolation search?
questions.ex: Interpolation search is an improved binary search that estimates position based on value distribution.

questions.q: In binary search, if array has duplicate elements, which occurrence is typically found?
questions.ex: Standard binary search finds any occurrence of duplicate elements, not necessarily first or last.

questions.q: What is the time complexity of finding all occurrences of an element using linear search?
questions.ex: To find all occurrences, we must check every element in the array, taking O(n) time.

questions.q: Binary search can be applied to:

questions.ex: Binary search works on any sorted data structure that supports random access (arrays, sorted lists).

questions.q: What is the lower bound for comparison-based searching in sorted array?

questions.q: In exponential search, what is the first step?

questions.q: What is the advantage of binary search over linear search?

questions.q: Which search algorithm has better worst-case performance?

questions.q: What is ternary search?
questions.ex: Ternary search divides array into three parts instead of two, comparing with two middle elements.

questions.q: In jump search, what is the optimal jump size for array of size n?
questions.ex: Jump search uses optimal jump size of √n to balance between jumps and linear search within block.

questions.q: What is the time complexity of jump search?

questions.q: Binary search is an example of which algorithm design technique?

questions.q: What is the time complexity of bubble sort in the worst case?

questions.q: What is the best case time complexity of bubble sort?

questions.q: Which sorting algorithm is stable?

questions.q: What is the space complexity of merge sort?
questions.ex: Merge sort requires O(n) auxiliary space for temporary arrays during the merging process.

questions.q: In quick sort, what is the purpose of the pivot element?
questions.ex: Pivot partitions array so that elements smaller than pivot are on left, larger ones on right.

questions.q: What is the worst case time complexity of quick sort?
questions.ex: Worst case occurs when pivot is always smallest/largest element, leading to unbalanced partitions: O(n²).

questions.q: What is the average case time complexity of quick sort?
questions.ex: Average case assumes balanced partitions, leading to O(n log n) time complexity.

questions.q: Which sorting algorithm uses divide and conquer approach?
questions.ex: Merge sort divides array into halves, sorts them recursively, then merges sorted halves.

questions.q: What is the space complexity of bubble sort?
questions.ex: Bubble sort sorts in-place, using only constant extra space for temporary variables: O(1).

questions.q: In bubble sort, after k passes, what can we guarantee?
options: Last k elements are in correct position
questions.ex: After k passes, the k largest elements 'bubble up' to their correct positions at the end.

questions.q: What is the time complexity of merge sort in all cases?
questions.ex: Merge sort consistently divides array into halves and merges in O(n), giving O(n log n) in all cases.

questions.q: Which pivot selection strategy helps avoid quick sort's worst case?
questions.ex: Random pivot selection reduces probability of consistently poor partitions, improving average performance.

questions.q: What is an adaptive sorting algorithm?
options: Performs better on partially sorted input
questions.ex: Adaptive algorithms like insertion sort perform better when input is already partially sorted.

questions.q: What is the recurrence relation for merge sort?
questions.ex: Merge sort divides into 2 subproblems of size n/2 and merges in O(n): T(n) = 2T(n/2) + O(n).

questions.ex: Counting sort uses key values as indices rather than comparing elements directly.

questions.q: What is the space complexity of in-place quick sort?

questions.q: Which algorithm is best for sorting linked lists?

questions.q: What is the invariant maintained by bubble sort?
questions.ex: Bubble sort maintains invariant that after i passes, the i largest elements are in correct positions.

questions.q: What is 3-way partitioning in quick sort?

questions.q: What is the lower bound for comparison-based sorting?

questions.q: Which sorting algorithm has the best space complexity?
questions.ex: Bubble sort uses O(1) space as it sorts in-place with only constant extra variables.

questions.q: What is external sorting?
questions.ex: External sorting handles datasets too large for main memory, using disk storage and merge techniques.

questions.q: In merge sort, what is the merge operation's time complexity?
questions.ex: Merging two sorted arrays of total size n requires examining each element once: O(n).

questions.q: What is the essential component that prevents infinite recursion?
questions.ex: Base case provides termination condition for recursion, preventing infinite recursive calls.

questions.q: What happens when a recursive function lacks a proper base case?
questions.ex: Without base case, recursive calls continue indefinitely until call stack is exhausted, causing stack overflow.

questions.q: What is the space complexity of a recursive function with maximum depth d?
questions.ex: Each recursive call uses stack space, so maximum depth d requires O(d) space for call stack.

questions.q: What is tail recursion?
options: Recursion at the end of program
Recursive call is the last operation
questions.ex: Tail recursion occurs when recursive call is the last operation in the function, allowing optimization.

questions.q: What is the time complexity of calculating factorial using recursion?
questions.ex: Factorial recursion makes n recursive calls: fact(n) → fact(n-1) → ... → fact(1), giving O(n).

questions.q: Which data structure is implicitly used in recursion?
questions.ex: System call stack stores function calls, parameters, and return addresses for recursive functions.

questions.q: What is the base case for calculating factorial of n?
questions.ex: Factorial base cases: 0! = 1 and 1! = 1, both return 1 to terminate recursion.

questions.q: What is direct recursion?
questions.ex: Direct recursion occurs when a function calls itself directly within its own definition.

questions.q: What is indirect recursion?
options: Function calls itself indirectly through other functions
questions.ex: Indirect recursion occurs when function A calls function B, which eventually calls function A.

questions.q: What is the time complexity of naive recursive Fibonacci calculation?
questions.ex: Naive Fibonacci recursion creates binary tree of calls with exponential growth: O(2^n).

questions.q: How can we optimize recursive Fibonacci calculation?
questions.ex: All approaches can optimize Fibonacci: iteration (O(n)), memoization (O(n)), and DP (O(n)).

questions.q: What is the recursive case in binary search?
questions.ex: Binary search recursively searches either left half (if target < mid) or right half (if target > mid).

questions.q: What is tree recursion?
questions.ex: Tree recursion occurs when function makes multiple recursive calls, creating tree-like call structure.

questions.q: What is the advantage of tail recursion?
questions.ex: Tail recursion can be optimized by compilers to iteration, eliminating stack overhead and using less memory.

questions.q: What is the recursive relation for Tower of Hanoi with n disks?
questions.ex: Tower of Hanoi: move n-1 disks, move largest disk, move n-1 disks again: T(n) = 2T(n-1) + 1.

questions.q: What is the minimum number of moves for Tower of Hanoi with n disks?
questions.ex: Tower of Hanoi requires minimum 2^n - 1 moves to transfer n disks following the rules.

questions.q: What is memoization in recursive functions?
questions.ex: Memoization stores results of expensive function calls to avoid redundant calculations in recursion.

questions.q: Which traversal algorithms use recursion naturally?

questions.q: What is the base case for recursive binary search?

questions.q: What is linear recursion?

questions.q: What is the space complexity of recursive factorial calculation?
questions.ex: Recursive factorial creates n stack frames for calls fact(n) to fact(1), requiring O(n) space.

questions.q: What is mutual recursion?
questions.ex: Mutual recursion occurs when two or more functions call each other recursively.

questions.q: What happens during the 'unwinding' phase of recursion?
questions.ex: Unwinding occurs when base case is reached and control returns through previous recursive calls.

questions.q: What is backtracking?

questions.q: What is the time complexity of recursive merge sort?
questions.ex: Merge sort recursion: T(n) = 2T(n/2) + O(n), which solves to O(n log n).

questions.q: What is primitive recursion?

questions.q: What is the recursive case for calculating power(x, n)?

questions.q: What is a database?
questions.ex: Database is an organized collection of related data stored and accessed electronically.

questions.q: What does DBMS stand for?
questions.ex: DBMS stands for Database Management System - software that manages database operations.

questions.q: What is the main advantage of using a database over file systems?
questions.ex: Databases eliminate data redundancy by storing each piece of data only once and providing controlled access.

questions.q: What is data redundancy?
questions.ex: Data redundancy occurs when same data is stored in multiple places, leading to inconsistency and waste.

questions.q: What is data integrity?
questions.ex: Data integrity ensures data accuracy, consistency, and reliability throughout its lifecycle.

questions.q: What is a Database Administrator (DBA)?
questions.ex: DBA is responsible for managing, maintaining, securing, and optimizing database systems.

questions.q: What is metadata?
questions.ex: Metadata is data that describes other data, including structure, constraints, and relationships.

questions.q: What is data independence?
options: Ability to change data structure without affecting applications
questions.ex: Data independence allows changes to data storage or structure without modifying application programs.

questions.q: What are the main components of a DBMS?
questions.ex: DBMS components include hardware, software, data, procedures, and people (users and administrators).

questions.q: What is concurrent access in databases?
questions.ex: Concurrent access allows multiple users to access and modify database simultaneously while maintaining consistency.

questions.q: What is data security in databases?
questions.ex: Data security involves protecting database from unauthorized access, modification, or destruction.

questions.q: What is the difference between data and information?
questions.ex: Data consists of raw facts, while information is processed data that provides meaningful insights.

questions.q: What is a database schema?
questions.ex: Database schema defines the logical structure, organization, and constraints of database elements.

questions.q: What is data abstraction in databases?
questions.ex: Data abstraction hides complex physical storage details and provides simplified logical view to users.

questions.q: What are the levels of data abstraction?
questions.ex: Three levels: Internal (physical storage), Conceptual (logical structure), External (user views).

questions.q: What is a database instance?
questions.ex: Database instance is the actual data stored in database at a specific point in time.

questions.q: What is the primary purpose of a database?
options: Efficient data storage, retrieval, and management
questions.ex: Databases provide efficient storage, retrieval, management, and sharing of data with integrity and security.

questions.q: What is data consistency?
options: Data remains accurate across all copies
questions.ex: Data consistency ensures all copies of data are identical and accurate throughout the system.

questions.q: What is a database transaction?
questions.ex: Transaction is a logical unit of database operations that must be completed entirely or not at all.

questions.q: What is data sharing in databases?
questions.ex: Data sharing allows multiple users and applications to access the same data simultaneously.

questions.q: What is the main disadvantage of file-based systems?
questions.ex: File systems suffer from data redundancy, inconsistency, and difficulty in data sharing and maintenance.

questions.q: What is database recovery?
questions.ex: Database recovery involves restoring database to consistent state after system failure or corruption.

questions.q: What is data dictionary?
questions.ex: Data dictionary is centralized repository containing metadata about database structure and constraints.

questions.q: What is database scalability?
questions.ex: Scalability refers to database's ability to handle increasing amounts of work or users efficiently.

questions.q: What is the role of database in modern applications?
questions.ex: Databases serve as central component managing data storage, retrieval, and consistency for applications.

questions.q: What is database backup?
questions.ex: Database backup is a copy of database data and structure used for recovery in case of failure.

questions.q: What is data mining?
questions.ex: Data mining involves discovering hidden patterns, relationships, and insights from large datasets.

questions.q: What is database performance?
questions.ex: Database performance measures speed, efficiency, and responsiveness of database operations.

questions.q: What is the main goal of database design?
questions.ex: Good database design minimizes redundancy, ensures data integrity, and supports efficient operations.

questions.q: What is database middleware?
questions.ex: Database middleware provides connectivity and communication layer between applications and database systems.

questions.q: What does RDBMS stand for?
questions.ex: RDBMS stands for Relational Database Management System, based on relational model.

questions.q: What is the main difference between DBMS and RDBMS?
options: RDBMS stores data in tables with relationships
questions.ex: RDBMS organizes data in tables (relations) with defined relationships, while DBMS may use various data models.

questions.q: Which of the following is an example of RDBMS?
questions.ex: MySQL is a relational database management system that stores data in tables with relationships.

questions.q: What is a table in RDBMS?
questions.ex: Table (relation) in RDBMS is a collection of rows (tuples) and columns (attributes) storing related data.

questions.q: What is normalization in RDBMS?
options: Process of organizing data to reduce redundancy
questions.ex: Normalization organizes data in tables to minimize redundancy and dependency issues.

questions.q: Which language is primarily used with RDBMS?
questions.ex: SQL (Structured Query Language) is the standard language for managing and querying relational databases.

questions.q: What is ACID compliance in RDBMS?
options: Set of properties ensuring reliable transactions
questions.ex: ACID (Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, Durability) ensures reliable database transaction processing.

questions.q: Can DBMS handle complex relationships between data?
questions.ex: Traditional DBMS has limited capability to handle complex relationships compared to RDBMS.

questions.q: What is a primary key in RDBMS?
questions.ex: Primary key uniquely identifies each row in a table and cannot contain NULL values.

questions.q: Which provides better data integrity?
questions.ex: RDBMS provides better data integrity through constraints, referential integrity, and ACID properties.

questions.q: What is a foreign key in RDBMS?
options: Field that links to primary key of another table
questions.ex: Foreign key is a field that creates link between two tables by referencing primary key of another table.

questions.q: Which system is more suitable for complex queries?
questions.ex: RDBMS with SQL support is better suited for complex queries involving multiple tables and relationships.

questions.q: What is referential integrity in RDBMS?
options: Ensuring foreign key references valid primary key
questions.ex: Referential integrity ensures foreign key values always reference existing primary key values.

questions.q: Which is more structured in data organization?
questions.ex: RDBMS is more structured with predefined schema, tables, and relationships.

questions.q: What is a relation in RDBMS?
questions.ex: Relation is the formal term for table in RDBMS, consisting of tuples (rows) and attributes (columns).

questions.q: Which supports better concurrent access?
questions.ex: RDBMS typically provides better concurrent access control with sophisticated locking mechanisms.

questions.q: What is the main advantage of RDBMS over DBMS?
questions.ex: RDBMS provides better data relationships, integrity constraints, and standardized query language (SQL).

questions.q: Which follows Codd's rules?
questions.ex: RDBMS follows Codd's 12 rules that define the relational model for database management.

questions.q: What is data redundancy control better in?
questions.ex: RDBMS provides better redundancy control through normalization and referential integrity.

questions.q: Which system requires more storage space?
questions.ex: RDBMS typically requires more storage due to metadata, indexes, and relationship information.

questions.q: What is schema in RDBMS?
questions.ex: Schema defines the structure of database including tables, columns, data types, and constraints.

questions.q: Which provides better backup and recovery?
questions.ex: RDBMS typically provides more sophisticated backup and recovery mechanisms with transaction logs.

questions.q: What is tuple in RDBMS?
questions.ex: Tuple is the formal term for row in RDBMS, representing a single record in a table.

questions.q: Which is more suitable for large-scale applications?
questions.ex: RDBMS is generally more suitable for large-scale applications due to better scalability and features.

questions.q: What is attribute in RDBMS?
questions.ex: Attribute is the formal term for column in RDBMS, representing a property of the relation.

questions.q: Which provides better security features?
questions.ex: RDBMS typically provides more comprehensive security features including user roles and access control.

questions.q: What is domain in RDBMS?
options: Set of allowable values for attribute
questions.ex: Domain defines the set of allowable values that an attribute can take in RDBMS.

questions.q: Which has better standardization?
questions.ex: RDBMS has better standardization with SQL as universal query language and relational model standards.

questions.q: What is cardinality in RDBMS?
questions.ex: Cardinality refers to the number of tuples (rows) in a relation (table) in RDBMS.

questions.q: Which is more complex to implement?
questions.ex: RDBMS is more complex to implement due to relational model, constraints, and additional features.

questions.q: Which SQL statement is used to extract data from a database?

questions.q: Which SQL operator is used for pattern matching?

questions.q: What is the purpose of the AS keyword in SQL?

questions.q: Which of the following is NOT a valid SQL data type?

questions.ex: The UNIQUE constraint ensures that all values in a column (or a combination of columns) are distinct.

questions.q: What is the default order when using ORDER BY?
questions.ex: By default, ORDER BY sorts the results in ascending order (ASC).

questions.q: Which operator is used to test for empty values (NULL values)?
questions.ex: The IS NULL and IS NOT NULL operators are used to check for NULL values in a column, as NULL is not equal to anything, including itself.

questions.q: Which SQL statement is used to define the database schema?
questions.ex: DDL (Data Definition Language) statements like CREATE, ALTER, and DROP are used to define and manage the database schema.

questions.q: Which of the following is a DML statement?
questions.ex: INSERT INTO is a DML (Data Manipulation Language) statement used for adding data to a table.

questions.q: Which operator is used to compare a value to a list of literal values or results of a subquery?
questions.ex: The IN operator is used to specify multiple possible values for a column in a WHERE clause.

questions.q: What is the purpose of the LIMIT clause in a SELECT statement?
options: To filter rows based on a condition
To group rows with the same values
To restrict the number of rows returned
questions.ex: The LIMIT clause is used to constrain the number of rows returned by a SELECT statement.

questions.q: Which statement is used to remove a table from the database?
questions.ex: The DROP TABLE statement is used to completely remove a table definition and all its data from the database.

questions.q: What does ER in ER Diagram stand for?
questions.ex: ER stands for Entity Relationship, a high-level conceptual data model.

questions.q: In an ER Diagram, what is represented by a rectangle?
questions.ex: Rectangles in an ER Diagram represent entity sets, which are collections of entities of the same type.

questions.q: In an ER Diagram, what is represented by an oval?
questions.ex: Ovals (or ellipses) in an ER Diagram represent attributes, which are properties of an entity or a relationship.

questions.q: In an ER Diagram, what is represented by a diamond?
questions.ex: Diamonds in an ER Diagram represent relationship sets, which are associations among two or more entity sets.

questions.q: What is an entity in the context of ER Diagrams?
questions.ex: An entity is a distinguishable real-world object or concept, such as a person, place, or event.

questions.q: What is an attribute in the context of ER Diagrams?
options: A characteristic or property of an entity or relationship
A unique identifier for an entity
questions.ex: An attribute is a descriptive property possessed by all members of an entity set or a relationship set.

questions.q: What is a relationship in the context of ER Diagrams?
options: An association among two or more entities
A unique identifier for an entity
questions.ex: A relationship is an association among two or more entities, representing how they are connected.

questions.q: What does cardinality represent in an ER Diagram?
options: The number of attributes in an entity
The number of relationships an entity participates in
The number of entities in an entity set
The number of instances of one entity that can be associated with an instance of another entity
questions.ex: Cardinality describes the number of instances of one entity that can be associated with an instance of another entity in a relationship.

questions.q: Which type of relationship is represented by a diamond with a double border in some ER notation?
questions.ex: A double-bordered diamond represents an identifying relationship, which connects a weak entity set to its identifying owner entity set.

questions.q: What is a weak entity set?
options: An entity set with many attributes
An entity set that does not have enough attributes to form a primary key on its own
An entity set with no relationships
An entity set that is less important than others
questions.ex: A weak entity set is an entity set that does not have a primary key of its own and depends on another entity set (the identifying owner) for its existence.

questions.q: What is the purpose of a primary key in the Relational Model?
options: To sort data in a table
To uniquely identify each row in a table
questions.ex: A primary key is a set of one or more attributes that uniquely identifies each tuple (row) in a relation (table).

questions.q: What is a foreign key in the Relational Model?
options: An attribute in one table that refers to the primary key of another table
A backup key for the primary key
questions.ex: A foreign key is an attribute or set of attributes in one relation that refers to the primary key of another relation, establishing a link between the tables.

questions.q: What is a relation in the Relational Model equivalent to?
questions.ex: In the Relational Model, a relation is equivalent to a table, which is a collection of tuples (rows) and attributes (columns).

questions.q: What is a tuple in the Relational Model equivalent to?
questions.ex: In the Relational Model, a tuple is equivalent to a row or a record in a table.

questions.q: What is an attribute in the Relational Model equivalent to?
questions.ex: In the Relational Model, an attribute is equivalent to a column or a field in a table.

questions.q: What does the degree of a relation refer to?
questions.ex: The degree of a relation is the number of attributes (columns) in the relation.

questions.q: What does the cardinality of a relation refer to?
questions.ex: The cardinality of a relation is the number of tuples (rows) in the relation.

questions.q: What is the purpose of mapping an ER Diagram to a Relational Model?
options: To translate the conceptual design into a logical database schema
To add more entities and relationships
questions.ex: Mapping an ER Diagram to a Relational Model is the process of converting the conceptual design into a set of tables with attributes, primary keys, and foreign keys, suitable for implementation in a relational database.

questions.q: Which type of relationship typically requires an intermediate table when mapping to a Relational Model?
questions.ex: A Many-to-Many relationship between two entity sets is typically represented by creating a new intermediate table (often called a junction or linking table) that includes the primary keys of both related entity sets as foreign keys.

questions.q: What is a superkey in the Relational Model?
options: Any key that can uniquely identify a row
The primary key of a table
A foreign key referencing another table
questions.ex: A superkey is any set of attributes that can uniquely identify a tuple in a relation. A primary key is a minimal superkey.

questions.q: What is a candidate key in the Relational Model?
options: Any attribute that is part of a foreign key
A minimal superkey that can uniquely identify a row
The primary key chosen for a table
questions.ex: A candidate key is a minimal superkey, meaning it is a superkey such that no proper subset of its attributes is also a superkey. A primary key is chosen from the set of candidate keys.

questions.q: In an ER Diagram, what does a double oval represent?
questions.ex: A double oval represents a multivalued attribute, which can have multiple values for a single entity instance (e.g., multiple phone numbers for a person).

questions.q: In an ER Diagram, what does an oval divided into smaller ovals represent?
questions.ex: An oval divided into smaller ovals represents a composite attribute, which can be divided into smaller sub-attributes (e.g., an Address attribute composed of Street, City, and Zip).

questions.q: In an ER Diagram, what does a dashed oval represent?
questions.ex: A dashed oval represents a derived attribute, which can be computed from other attributes (e.g., Age derived from Date of Birth).

questions.q: What is participation constraint in an ER Diagram?
options: The number of attributes in an entity
The number of entities in a set
Whether the existence of an entity depends on its being related to another entity via a relationship set
The number of relationships between entities
questions.ex: Participation constraint specifies whether the existence of an entity is dependent on its participation in a relationship. Total participation (double line) means every entity in the set must participate, while partial participation (single line) means some entities may not.

questions.q: What is the main principle of the Relational Model?
options: Data is stored in a hierarchical structure
Data is stored in a network structure
Data is stored in tables (relations) with relationships defined by foreign keys
Data is stored as key-value pairs
questions.ex: The Relational Model is based on the concept of storing data in two-dimensional tables (relations) and defining relationships between these tables using shared attributes, primarily foreign keys.

questions.q: What is a schema in the context of the Relational Model?
options: The actual data stored in the tables
The structure of the database, including table definitions, attributes, and constraints
The queries used to access the data
The user interface for the database
questions.ex: The schema in the Relational Model defines the logical structure of the database, specifying the tables, their attributes, data types, and constraints.

questions.q: Which of the following is NOT a component of the Relational Model?
questions.ex: The Relational Model does not rely on pointers to connect data. Relationships are established through shared attribute values (foreign keys).

questions.q: What is a relationship set in an ER Diagram?
options: A collection of relationships of the same type
A unique identifier for a relationship
questions.ex: A relationship set is a collection of relationships of the same type among instances of one or more entity sets.

questions.q: What is the primary goal of database normalization?
options: To reduce data redundancy and improve data integrity
To increase the size of the database
questions.ex: The main goal of normalization is to minimize data redundancy and eliminate undesirable data anomalies (insertion, update, and deletion anomalies).

questions.q: Which of the following is NOT a data anomaly that normalization helps to avoid?
questions.ex: Normalization primarily addresses insertion, deletion, and update anomalies, which occur due to data redundancy. Query anomaly is not a standard term related to normalization.

questions.q: What is the first normal form (1NF)?
options: All attributes are atomic and there are no repeating groups
Every non-key attribute is fully functionally dependent on the primary key
Every non-key attribute is non-transitively dependent on the primary key
Every determinant is a candidate key
questions.ex: A relation is in 1NF if all attribute values are atomic (indivisible) and there are no repeating groups (multiple values in a single cell).

questions.q: What is the second normal form (2NF)?
options: All attributes are atomic and there are no repeating groups
Every non-key attribute is fully functionally dependent on the primary key
Every non-key attribute is non-transitively dependent on the primary key
Every determinant is a candidate key
questions.ex: A relation is in 2NF if it is in 1NF and every non-key attribute is fully functionally dependent on the primary key (no partial dependencies).

questions.q: What is the third normal form (3NF)?
options: All attributes are atomic and there are no repeating groups
Every non-key attribute is fully functionally dependent on the primary key
Every non-key attribute is non-transitively dependent on the primary key
Every determinant is a candidate key
questions.ex: A relation is in 3NF if it is in 2NF and every non-key attribute is non-transitively dependent on the primary key (no transitive dependencies).

questions.q: What is a functional dependency?
options: A constraint that describes the relationship between attributes
questions.ex: A functional dependency is a constraint between two sets of attributes in a relation. If A functionally determines B (A -> B), it means that for any two tuples in the relation, if they have the same value for A, they must also have the same value for B.

questions.q: What is a partial dependency?
options: A dependency where a non-key attribute is dependent on only part of a composite primary key
A dependency between two non-key attributes
A dependency where a key attribute is dependent on a non-key attribute
A dependency that involves all attributes in the relation
questions.ex: A partial dependency occurs when a non-key attribute is functionally dependent on only a part of a composite primary key.

questions.q: What is a transitive dependency?
options: A dependency where a non-key attribute is dependent on another non-key attribute
A dependency where a non-key attribute is dependent on the primary key
A dependency where a key attribute is dependent on a non-key attribute
A dependency that involves only two attributes
questions.ex: A transitive dependency occurs when a non-key attribute is indirectly dependent on the primary key through another non-key attribute (A -> B and B -> C, where A is the primary key and B and C are non-key attributes).

questions.q: Boyce-Codd Normal Form (BCNF) is stricter than which normal form?
questions.ex: BCNF is a stricter version of 3NF. A relation is in BCNF if for every non-trivial functional dependency X -> Y, X is a superkey.

questions.q: When is a relation in BCNF?
options: If it is in 3NF and every non-key attribute is fully functionally dependent on the primary key
If every determinant is a candidate key
If there are no partial dependencies
If there are no transitive dependencies
questions.ex: A relation is in BCNF if for every non-trivial functional dependency X -> Y, X is a superkey. This means that every determinant (the left side of a functional dependency) must be a candidate key.

questions.q: Which normal form eliminates partial dependencies?
questions.ex: The second normal form (2NF) eliminates partial dependencies by requiring that every non-key attribute be fully functionally dependent on the primary key.

questions.q: Which normal form eliminates transitive dependencies?
questions.ex: The third normal form (3NF) eliminates transitive dependencies by requiring that every non-key attribute be non-transitively dependent on the primary key.

questions.q: Which normal form is considered desirable for most database designs?
questions.ex: Third normal form (3NF) is generally considered a good balance between reducing redundancy and maintaining performance for most database applications.

questions.q: What can be a disadvantage of excessive normalization?
options: More complex queries due to joins
questions.ex: Excessive normalization (going beyond what is necessary) can lead to a large number of tables, requiring more complex queries with multiple joins, which can sometimes impact performance.

questions.q: If a relation is in BCNF, is it also in 3NF?
options: Only if it has a single primary key
Only if it has no non-key attributes
questions.ex: Yes, BCNF is a stricter form of 3NF. If a relation is in BCNF, it automatically satisfies the conditions for 3NF.

questions.q: If a relation is in 3NF, is it always in BCNF?
options: Only if there are no overlapping candidate keys
Only if there are no non-key attributes
questions.ex: No, a relation in 3NF is not necessarily in BCNF. A relation might be in 3NF but not BCNF if there are overlapping candidate keys and a non-key attribute is functionally dependent on a determinant that is not a candidate key.

questions.q: Which normal form is characterized by the rule 'Every non-key attribute is dependent on the key, the whole key, and nothing but the key'?
questions.ex: This phrase is a mnemonic for 3NF, addressing the elimination of partial and transitive dependencies. 'Dependent on the key' relates to 1NF, 'the whole key' relates to 2NF (full functional dependency), and 'nothing but the key' relates to 3NF (non-transitive dependency).

questions.q: Denormalization is sometimes performed for what reason?
options: To make the database design more complex
questions.ex: Denormalization is the process of intentionally introducing redundancy or grouping data to improve query performance, often by reducing the number of joins required.

questions.q: What is the definition of a superkey?
options: An attribute that uniquely identifies a tuple
A set of attributes that uniquely identifies a tuple
The primary key of a relation
A foreign key referencing another relation
questions.ex: A superkey is any set of attributes that uniquely identifies each tuple in a relation.

questions.q: What is the definition of a candidate key?
options: An attribute that is part of a foreign key
The primary key chosen for a table
questions.ex: A candidate key is a minimal superkey, meaning it is a superkey from which no attribute can be removed without losing the uniqueness property.

questions.q: Which normal form deals with multi-valued dependencies?
questions.ex: Fourth Normal Form (4NF) addresses multi-valued dependencies.

questions.q: Which normal form deals with join dependencies?
questions.ex: Fifth Normal Form (5NF), also known as Project-Join Normal Form (PJNF), addresses join dependencies.

questions.q: What is the update anomaly?
options: Difficulty inserting new data without having related data
Difficulty deleting data without losing related data
Inconsistency in data when updating redundant information
Inability to query the database correctly
questions.ex: An update anomaly occurs when redundant data is not updated consistently across all its occurrences, leading to data inconsistency.

questions.q: What is the insertion anomaly?
options: Difficulty inserting new data without having related data
Difficulty deleting data without losing related data
Inconsistency in data when updating redundant information
Inability to query the database correctly
questions.ex: An insertion anomaly occurs when it is not possible to insert data about a new entity without having data about another related entity.

questions.q: What is the deletion anomaly?
options: Difficulty inserting new data without having related data
Difficulty deleting data without losing related data
Inconsistency in data when updating redundant information
Inability to query the database correctly
questions.ex: A deletion anomaly occurs when deleting data about one entity unintentionally deletes data about another related entity because the data is stored together.

questions.q: Which of the following is a property of a relation in any normal form (including 1NF)?
options: Every determinant is a candidate key
questions.ex: The fundamental requirement for a relation to be in First Normal Form (1NF) is that all its attribute values must be atomic and there should be no repeating groups.

questions.q: Which key is used to uniquely identify each row in a database table?
questions.ex: The primary key is a special type of candidate key chosen to uniquely identify each tuple (row) in a relation (table).

questions.q: Which key is an attribute or set of attributes in one table that refers to the primary key of another table?
questions.ex: A foreign key is used to establish and enforce a link between data in two tables, referencing the primary key of the related table.

questions.q: Which of the following is a set of one or more attributes that can uniquely identify a tuple in a relation?
questions.ex: A superkey is any set of attributes that, taken together, can uniquely identify a record in a table.

questions.q: Which of the following is a minimal superkey?
questions.ex: A candidate key is a superkey such that no proper subset of its attributes is also a superkey. It is a minimal set of attributes that can uniquely identify a tuple.

questions.q: Can a primary key contain NULL values?
options: Only if it's a composite key
questions.ex: A primary key constraint enforces both uniqueness and NOT NULL constraints. Therefore, a primary key cannot contain NULL values.

questions.q: Can a foreign key contain NULL values?
options: Only if the referenced primary key is NULL
questions.ex: Yes, a foreign key can contain NULL values, unless the foreign key column is also defined with a NOT NULL constraint.

questions.q: What is the purpose of an index in a database?
options: To store data in a sorted order
To improve the speed of data retrieval operations
questions.ex: Indexes are data structures that improve the speed of data retrieval operations on a database table, similar to an index in a book.

questions.q: Which type of index physically orders the data in the table according to the index key?
questions.ex: A clustered index determines the physical order of data in a table. A table can have only one clustered index.

questions.q: Which type of index does NOT affect the physical order of data in the table but stores the index data separately from the actual data?
questions.ex: A non-clustered index stores the index structure (key values and pointers to data rows) separately from the table data. A table can have multiple non-clustered indexes.

questions.q: Which key is used to enforce uniqueness on a column or set of columns, but unlike a primary key, it can allow one NULL value?
questions.ex: A unique key constraint ensures that all values in a column or set of columns are unique. In most SQL implementations, a unique key allows one NULL value.

questions.q: Which of the following statements about indexes is generally true?
options: Indexes speed up both data retrieval and data modification operations
Indexes speed up data retrieval but can slow down data modification operations
Indexes slow down data retrieval but speed up data modification operations
Indexes have no impact on data retrieval or modification speed
questions.ex: Indexes significantly speed up SELECT queries (data retrieval). However, they can slow down INSERT, UPDATE, and DELETE operations because the index structure must also be updated.

questions.q: What is a composite key?
options: A key that consists of a single attribute
A key that consists of two or more attributes
A key that is used to establish relationships between tables
A key that uniquely identifies a foreign table
questions.ex: A composite key is a key (primary, unique, or foreign) that is made up of two or more attributes.

questions.q: Which key is used to establish relationships between tables and maintain referential integrity?
questions.ex: Foreign keys are crucial for linking related tables and enforcing referential integrity, ensuring that relationships between data are valid.

questions.q: What is a secondary key?
options: A key used to uniquely identify a row
A key used to establish relationships between tables
An attribute or set of attributes that can be used for retrieval purposes, but does not necessarily uniquely identify a row
The primary key of a related table
questions.ex: A secondary key (or alternate key) is a candidate key that is not chosen as the primary key. It can still be used for indexing and searching, but it is not the main unique identifier.

questions.q: When is it generally beneficial to create an index on a column?
options: When the column is rarely used in WHERE clauses
When the column has a small number of distinct values
When the column is frequently used in WHERE clauses or for sorting
When the table is very small
questions.ex: Indexes are most beneficial on columns that are frequently used in filtering (WHERE clauses), joining tables, or sorting results (ORDER BY clauses).

questions.q: What happens when you define a Primary Key on a column?
options: A foreign key is automatically created
A clustered index is typically created automatically (though this can vary by RDBMS)
The column can contain NULL values
questions.ex: In most relational database management systems (RDBMS), defining a primary key constraint automatically creates a clustered index on that column(s), which physically orders the data.

questions.q: What is the purpose of referential integrity, enforced by foreign keys?
options: To ensure that all data is unique
To prevent actions that would destroy links between tables
To improve the performance of joins
To encrypt data in related tables
questions.ex: Referential integrity ensures that relationships between tables are maintained. For example, it prevents deleting a row in a parent table if there are dependent rows in a child table (unless specified otherwise).

questions.q: Which of the following is a key that is chosen from the set of candidate keys to be the main unique identifier for a relation?
questions.ex: The primary key is the selected candidate key that serves as the principal means of identifying tuples in a relation.

questions.q: What is an index scan?
options: Reading every row in the table
Reading only the rows that match the index key
Updating the index after data modification
questions.ex: An index scan involves reading entries from the index to locate the relevant data rows, which is typically much faster than scanning the entire table (table scan).

questions.q: What is the role of a surrogate key?
options: A system-generated key with no intrinsic meaning, used as a primary key
A key composed of multiple attributes
questions.ex: A surrogate key is an artificial key, typically a system-generated number, used as a primary key when natural keys are complex, unstable, or non-existent. It has no business meaning.

questions.q: Which type of index is best suited for columns with a low cardinality (few distinct values)?
questions.ex: Bitmap indexes are efficient for columns with low cardinality because they use bitmaps (sequences of bits) to represent the presence or absence of values, which is space-efficient for few distinct values.

questions.q: What is an index seek?
options: Reading every row in the table
Directly locating specific rows using the index structure
questions.ex: An index seek is the most efficient way to use an index. It involves directly navigating the index structure (like a tree) to find the location of specific data rows based on the search key.

questions.q: Which type of index is the most common and is implemented as a balanced tree structure?
questions.ex: B-tree indexes are the most widely used type of index in relational databases due to their efficiency in handling a wide range of queries, including exact matches and range queries.

questions.q: What is a covering index?
options: An index that includes all columns in the table
An index that includes all columns required to satisfy a query, so the database does not need to access the table data
An index that covers multiple tables
An index that is automatically created
questions.ex: A covering index is an index that includes all the columns needed for a specific query, allowing the database to retrieve all required data directly from the index without having to access the base table, which can significantly improve performance.

questions.q: Which key is used to uniquely identify a record within a table, and is often the same as the primary key?
questions.ex: While a candidate key can uniquely identify a record, the primary key is the specific candidate key designated as the principal identifier for the table.

questions.q: What is a database transaction?
options: A collection of database operations that are treated as a single logical unit of work
questions.ex: A transaction is a sequence of one or more database operations (like SELECT, INSERT, UPDATE, DELETE) that are executed as a single, indivisible unit. Either all operations in a transaction are completed successfully, or none of them are.

questions.q: What does the 'A' in ACID properties stand for?
questions.ex: ACID is an acronym for Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, and Durability, which are properties guaranteeing reliable transaction processing.

questions.q: What does the 'C' in ACID properties stand for?
questions.ex: Consistency ensures that a transaction brings the database from one valid state to another, maintaining all data integrity rules.

questions.q: What does the 'I' in ACID properties stand for?
questions.ex: Isolation ensures that concurrent transactions do not interfere with each other. The outcome of concurrent transactions should be the same as if they were executed sequentially.

questions.q: What does the 'D' in ACID properties stand for?
questions.ex: Durability ensures that once a transaction is committed, its changes are permanent and will survive system failures.

questions.q: Which ACID property ensures that either all operations of a transaction are completed, or none are?
questions.ex: Atomicity means that a transaction is treated as an atomic unit. If any part of the transaction fails, the entire transaction is rolled back, leaving the database unchanged.

questions.q: What is concurrency control in databases?
options: Managing simultaneous access to the database by multiple users or applications
Controlling the flow of data in the network
Ensuring that transactions are executed quickly
Securing the database from unauthorized access
questions.ex: Concurrency control is the management of simultaneous operations on a database to ensure data consistency and isolation among concurrent transactions.

questions.q: Which of the following is a common technique used for concurrency control?
questions.ex: Locking is a widely used concurrency control mechanism where transactions acquire locks on data items to prevent other transactions from accessing or modifying them simultaneously.

questions.q: What is a deadlock in the context of database concurrency?
options: A transaction that fails to commit
A situation where two or more transactions are blocked indefinitely, waiting for each other to release resources
A performance issue caused by too many concurrent transactions
A failure to connect to the database
questions.ex: A deadlock occurs when two or more transactions are in a circular waiting state, each holding a resource that the others need.

questions.q: Which isolation level allows a transaction to read data that has been modified by another transaction but not yet committed?
questions.ex: Read Uncommitted is the lowest isolation level and allows transactions to see uncommitted changes made by other transactions, leading to dirty reads.

questions.q: Which isolation level ensures that a transaction only reads data that has been committed?
questions.ex: Read Committed ensures that a transaction only reads data that has been committed by other transactions, preventing dirty reads.

questions.q: Which isolation level prevents non-repeatable reads?
questions.ex: Repeatable Read ensures that if a transaction reads a row multiple times, it will always see the same data, preventing non-repeatable reads.

questions.q: Which isolation level provides the highest level of isolation, preventing dirty reads, non-repeatable reads, and phantom reads?
questions.ex: Serializable is the highest isolation level and ensures that concurrent transactions produce the same result as if they were executed sequentially, preventing all types of read anomalies.

questions.q: What is a phantom read?
options: Reading the same data multiple times and getting different values
Reading a set of rows and then re-reading the same query and getting a different set of rows (due to insertions or deletions by other transactions)
questions.ex: A phantom read occurs when a transaction reads a set of rows based on a condition, and then another transaction inserts or deletes rows that match the condition, so a subsequent read by the first transaction returns a different set of rows.

questions.q: What is a dirty read?
options: Reading data that has been modified by another transaction but not yet committed
Reading data that has been deleted
questions.ex: A dirty read occurs when a transaction reads data that has been written by another transaction that has not yet committed. If the other transaction is rolled back, the first transaction will have read invalid data.

questions.q: What is a non-repeatable read?
options: Reading the same data multiple times within the same transaction and getting different values (due to updates by other committed transactions)
Reading a set of rows and then re-reading the same query and getting a different set of rows
questions.ex: A non-repeatable read occurs when a transaction reads a row, and then another transaction updates or deletes that row and commits. A subsequent read of the same row by the first transaction will yield different data or indicate the row is deleted.

questions.q: Which concurrency control protocol requires transactions to obtain all locks before starting any operations?
questions.ex: Two-Phase Locking (2PL) is a concurrency control protocol that ensures serializability by dividing transaction execution into two phases: a growing phase (acquiring locks) and a shrinking phase (releasing locks).

questions.q: What is the growing phase in Two-Phase Locking (2PL)?
options: The phase where a transaction releases locks
The phase where a transaction acquires locks
The phase where a transaction performs data modifications
The phase where a transaction reads data
questions.ex: In the growing phase of 2PL, a transaction can acquire locks but cannot release any locks.

questions.q: What is the shrinking phase in Two-Phase Locking (2PL)?
options: The phase where a transaction acquires locks
The phase where a transaction releases locks
The phase where a transaction performs data modifications
The phase where a transaction reads data
questions.ex: In the shrinking phase of 2PL, a transaction can release locks but cannot acquire any new locks.

questions.q: Which concurrency control technique assigns a unique timestamp to each transaction to order their execution?
questions.ex: Timestamp Ordering is a concurrency control technique that uses timestamps assigned to transactions to determine the order in which they should be executed to ensure serializability.

questions.q: What is a distributed transaction?
options: A transaction that accesses data in multiple tables
A transaction that involves multiple users
A transaction that accesses data stored across multiple databases or locations
A transaction that uses distributed processing
questions.ex: A distributed transaction is a transaction that performs operations on data located in multiple, geographically separated databases or data sources.

questions.q: Which protocol is commonly used to ensure atomicity in distributed transactions?
questions.ex: Two-Phase Commit (2PC) is a distributed consensus algorithm used to ensure that all participants in a distributed transaction either commit or abort the transaction together, guaranteeing atomicity.

questions.q: What is the role of the coordinator in a Two-Phase Commit (2PC) protocol?
options: To manage the locks for all participants
To orchestrate the commit or abort decision among all participants
questions.ex: The coordinator in 2PC is responsible for initiating the commit process and coordinating with all participating nodes to reach a unanimous decision on whether to commit or abort the transaction.

questions.q: In the context of transactions, what does 'rollback' mean?
options: To save the changes made by a transaction
To undo all changes made by a transaction and restore the database to its state before the transaction started
To apply the changes made by a transaction
questions.ex: Rolling back a transaction means undoing all the operations performed by that transaction, effectively canceling its effects and restoring the database to its state before the transaction began.

questions.q: In the context of transactions, what does 'commit' mean?
options: To undo all changes made by a transaction
To save the changes made by a transaction permanently to the database
questions.ex: Committing a transaction means making all the changes performed by the transaction permanent in the database. Once a transaction is committed, its changes are visible to other transactions and are guaranteed to be durable.

questions.q: What does LAN stand for?
questions.ex: LAN stands for Local Area Network, which covers a small geographical area.

questions.q: What does WAN stand for?
questions.ex: WAN stands for Wide Area Network, which covers a large geographical area, often connecting multiple LANs.

questions.q: What does MAN stand for?
questions.ex: MAN stands for Metropolitan Area Network, which typically covers the area of a city or a large campus.

questions.q: Which type of network typically covers a single building or a small campus?
questions.ex: A Local Area Network (LAN) is designed to cover a limited geographical area, such as an office building, school, or home.

questions.q: Which type of network typically covers a large geographical area, spanning across cities, states, or even countries?
questions.ex: A Wide Area Network (WAN) connects devices over vast distances and is often used to link multiple LANs together.

questions.q: Which type of network typically covers the area of a city or a large metropolitan region?
questions.ex: A Metropolitan Area Network (MAN) is designed to cover a metropolitan area, providing connectivity within a city or a large campus.

questions.q: Which type of network is often privately owned and managed?
questions.ex: LANs are typically privately owned and managed by the organization or individual using them.

questions.q: Which type of network often utilizes public telecommunication lines or services?
questions.ex: WANs often rely on public infrastructure like telephone lines, fiber optic cables, or satellite links to connect distant locations.

questions.q: Which type of network typically has the highest data transfer rates and lowest latency?
questions.ex: Due to their limited geographical scope and dedicated infrastructure, LANs generally offer higher bandwidth and lower latency compared to MANs and WANs.

questions.q: The Internet is an example of which type of network?
questions.ex: The Internet is the largest example of a Wide Area Network (WAN), connecting networks globally.

questions.q: A network connecting different buildings within a university campus is an example of which type of network?
