Combining data and methods into a single unit
Having multiple functions with the same name but different parameters
Hiding the implementation details of a class
questions.ex: Inheritance allows a new class (derived class or subclass) to inherit attributes and methods from an existing class (base class or superclass), promoting code reusability.

questions.q: What is polymorphism in Object-Oriented Programming?
options: Creating a new class based on an existing class
Combining data and methods into a single unit
The ability of an object or function to take on multiple forms or have multiple implementations
Hiding the implementation details of a class
questions.ex: Polymorphism means 'many forms'. In OOP, it allows objects of different classes to be treated as objects of a common superclass, and a single function call can result in different behaviors depending on the object's actual type.

questions.q: What is encapsulation in Object-Oriented Programming?
options: Creating a new class based on an existing class
Combining data and methods that operate on the data into a single unit (a class), and often hiding the internal implementation details
Having multiple functions with the same name but different parameters
Allowing objects to take on multiple forms
questions.ex: Encapsulation is the bundling of data (attributes) and the methods (functions) that operate on that data into a single unit (a class). It often involves data hiding to protect the internal state of an object.

questions.q: Which keyword is used to declare a constant in C++?
questions.ex: The `const` keyword is used to declare variables whose values cannot be changed after initialization.

questions.q: What is the purpose of the `include` directive in C/C++?
options: To include the content of another file (usually a header file) into the current file
To execute a block of code repeatedly
questions.ex: The `#include` preprocessor directive tells the compiler to insert the content of the specified header file into the source code before compilation.

questions.q: What is the difference between `==` and `=` in C/C++?
options: `==` is for assignment, `=` is for comparison
`==` is for comparison, `=` is for assignment
questions.ex: The `==` operator is used for comparison (checking if two values are equal), while the `=` operator is used for assignment (assigning a value to a variable).

questions.q: What is a destructor in C++?
options: A function that initializes an object
A function that is automatically called when an object is destroyed (goes out of scope or is deleted) to clean up resources
A function that creates a new object
questions.ex: A destructor is a special member function of a class that is automatically invoked when an object of that class is destroyed. It is typically used to release resources (like allocated memory) held by the object.

questions.q: What is a constructor in C++?
options: A function that cleans up resources
A function that is automatically called when an object of a class is created to initialize its members
A function that deletes an object
questions.ex: A constructor is a special member function of a class that is automatically called when an object of that class is created. It is used to initialize the object's member variables.

questions.q: What is memory allocation?
options: Assigning memory space for variables and data structures
questions.ex: Memory allocation is the process of reserving space in the computer's memory for storing data that will be used by a program.

questions.q: What is memory deallocation?
options: Freeing up memory space that is no longer needed by a program
questions.ex: Memory deallocation is the process of releasing memory space that was previously allocated to a program, making it available for other programs to use.

questions.q: In C++, what is the purpose of the `namespace` keyword?
options: To organize code into logical groups and prevent naming conflicts
questions.ex: Namespaces provide a way to group related declarations (like classes, functions, variables) under a unique name to avoid naming conflicts, especially in large projects or when using libraries.

questions.q: What is function overloading in C++?
options: Defining multiple functions with different names but the same parameters
Defining multiple functions with the same name but different parameters or number of parameters
Defining a function within another function
Defining a function that calls itself
questions.ex: Function overloading allows you to define multiple functions in the same scope with the same name but with different parameter lists (different types, order, or number of parameters).

questions.q: What is operator overloading in C++?
options: Giving operators different meanings based on the context (the types of operands)
Using multiple operators in a single expression
questions.ex: Operator overloading allows you to redefine the way operators work for user-defined data types (classes), giving them special meanings when applied to objects of those classes.

questions.q: What is the difference between `struct` in C and `struct` in C++?
options: In C, `struct` can contain member functions, but in C++ it cannot
In C++, `struct` can contain member functions and has features similar to a class (with members public by default), while in C it can only contain data members
In C, `struct` can have access specifiers (public/private), but in C++ it cannot
questions.ex: In C++, `struct` is essentially a class where members are public by default. It can have both data members and member functions. In C, `struct` can only contain data members.

questions.q: What is the purpose of the `this` pointer in C++?
options: To point to the next object in a list
To point to the base class object
To point to the current object that the member function is being called on
To point to a null value
questions.ex: The `this` pointer is a special pointer in C++ that points to the object for which a member function is called. It is implicitly used to access the members of the current object.

questions.q: What is the role of the `virtual` keyword in C++?
options: To make a function accessible from anywhere
To indicate that a function can be overloaded
To enable polymorphism by allowing a derived class's version of a function to be called through a base class pointer or reference
questions.ex: The `virtual` keyword is used in the base class to declare a member function that is expected to be overridden by derived classes. This enables dynamic polymorphism (runtime binding).

questions.q: What is an abstract class in C++?
options: A class that cannot have any member functions
A class that contains at least one pure virtual function and cannot be instantiated directly
A class that can only be used for inheritance
A class that has no member variables
questions.ex: An abstract class is a class that is designed to be a base class for other classes. It contains at least one pure virtual function (a virtual function with `= 0`). You cannot create objects directly from an abstract class.

questions.q: What is a pure virtual function in C++?
options: A virtual function that has already been implemented
A virtual function declared with `= 0` at the end of its declaration in the base class, indicating that derived classes must provide an implementation
A virtual function that returns no value
A virtual function that cannot be overridden
questions.ex: A pure virtual function is a virtual function in a base class that has no implementation (`= 0`). It forces derived classes to provide their own implementation of that function.

questions.q: What is dynamic memory allocation in C/C++?
options: Allocating memory on the heap during program execution
questions.ex: Dynamic memory allocation involves allocating memory from the heap (a region of memory for dynamic allocation) during the runtime of the program, using functions like `malloc` and `calloc` in C, and operators `new` and `delete` in C++.

questions.q: What is the purpose of the `new` operator in C++?
options: To allocate memory dynamically on the heap for an object or an array of objects
To create a new variable on the stack
questions.ex: The `new` operator is used in C++ to allocate memory dynamically for an object or an array of objects on the heap and returns a pointer to the allocated memory.

questions.q: What is the purpose of the `delete` operator in C++?
options: To deallocate memory that was previously allocated with `new`
To delete a variable from the stack
To delete a file from the system
questions.ex: The `delete` operator is used in C++ to deallocate memory that was previously allocated using the `new` operator, freeing up that memory for reuse.

questions.q: What is the main characteristic of Java?
questions.ex: Java is designed to be platform-independent. Java source code is compiled into bytecode, which can then be executed on any platform with a Java Virtual Machine (JVM).

questions.q: What does JVM stand for?
questions.ex: JVM stands for Java Virtual Machine, which is a virtual machine that executes Java bytecode.

questions.q: What is the file extension for a Java source code file?
questions.ex: Java source code files have the `.java` extension.

questions.q: What is the file extension for a Java bytecode file?
questions.ex: When Java source code is compiled, it is translated into bytecode, which is stored in files with the `.class` extension.

questions.q: Which keyword is used to declare a class in Java?
questions.ex: The `class` keyword is used to define a class in Java.

questions.q: What is an object in Java?
options: A variable that stores a single value
questions.ex: An object is a concrete instance of a class. When an object is created, it has its own state (values of instance variables) and can perform actions (call methods).

questions.q: What is a method in Java?
options: A variable that stores a value
A block of code that performs a specific task and can be called
questions.ex: A method in Java is a function that belongs to a class or an object. It defines the behavior of the object.

questions.q: What is the entry point for the execution of a standalone Java application?
questions.ex: The `main` method (specifically `public static void main(String[] args)`) is the starting point for the execution of a Java application.

questions.q: Which keyword is used to create an object of a class in Java?
questions.ex: The `new` keyword is used to create a new object (an instance) of a class.

questions.q: What is inheritance in Java?
options: Combining data and methods into a single unit
Having multiple methods with the same name but different parameters
A mechanism where one class acquires the properties (fields and methods) of another class
Hiding the implementation details of a class
questions.ex: Inheritance allows a class (subclass or derived class) to inherit attributes and methods from another class (superclass or base class), promoting code reusability.

questions.q: What is polymorphism in Java?
options: A mechanism where one class acquires the properties of another class
Combining data and methods into a single unit
Having multiple methods with the same name but different parameters
The ability of an object to take on many forms, allowing a single method call to perform different actions based on the object's type
questions.ex: Polymorphism in Java allows objects of different classes to be treated as objects of a common superclass, and a single method call can result in different behaviors depending on the actual type of the object.

questions.q: What is encapsulation in Java?
options: A mechanism where one class acquires the properties of another class
Combining data (fields) and the methods that operate on that data into a single unit (a class), and often restricting direct access to the data
Having multiple methods with the same name but different parameters
The ability of an object to take on many forms
questions.ex: Encapsulation bundles data and methods within a class. Access modifiers (like `private`) are used to control access to the data, often requiring methods (getters and setters) to interact with it.

questions.q: Which access modifier makes a member accessible only within its own class?
questions.ex: The `private` access modifier restricts access to members so they can only be accessed within the class where they are declared.

questions.q: Which access modifier makes a member accessible within its own class, by subclasses, and within the same package?
questions.ex: The `protected` access modifier allows members to be accessed within the same class, by subclasses (in any package), and by classes within the same package.

questions.q: Which access modifier makes a member accessible from anywhere?
questions.ex: The `public` access modifier allows members to be accessed from any other class.

questions.q: What is the default access modifier in Java?
questions.ex: If no access modifier is specified, the member has default (package-private) access, meaning it is accessible only within the same package.

questions.q: What is the purpose of the `super` keyword in Java?
options: To refer to the current object
To refer to the superclass (parent class) of an object
To refer to a static member of a class
questions.ex: The `super` keyword is used to refer to the immediate superclass of a class, often used to access members (fields or methods) of the superclass that are hidden by members in the subclass, or to call the superclass constructor.

questions.q: What is method overloading in Java?
options: Defining a method in a subclass with the same name and signature as a method in the superclass
Defining multiple methods in the same class with the same name but different parameter lists
Defining a method that calls itself
Defining a method with a variable number of arguments
questions.ex: Method overloading allows a class to have multiple methods with the same name, provided that their parameter lists are different (different types, order, or number of parameters).

questions.q: What is method overriding in Java?
options: Defining multiple methods in the same class with the same name but different parameter lists
Defining a method in a subclass with the same name and signature (name and parameter list) as a method in the superclass
Defining a method that calls itself
Defining a method with a variable number of arguments
questions.ex: Method overriding occurs when a subclass provides its own implementation of a method that is already defined in its superclass. The method in the subclass has the same name, return type, and parameter list as the method in the superclass.

questions.q: What is an abstract class in Java?
options: A class that cannot have any member variables
A class that cannot have any methods
A class that cannot be instantiated and may contain abstract methods (methods without an implementation)
A class that can only be used for inheritance
questions.ex: An abstract class is a class that is declared with the `abstract` keyword. It cannot be instantiated directly but can be subclassed. It may contain both abstract methods (declared with `abstract` and no body) and concrete methods.

questions.q: What is an interface in Java?
options: A class that cannot be instantiated
A blueprint of a class, containing abstract methods and constants, that a class can implement
A type of data structure for storing key-value pairs
questions.ex: An interface is a contract that defines a set of methods that a class must implement. It contains only method signatures and constants (in older versions of Java; newer versions allow default and static methods).

questions.q: What is exception handling in Java?
options: A mechanism to deal with abnormal conditions (exceptions) that occur during the execution of a program
questions.ex: Exception handling in Java uses `try`, `catch`, and `finally` blocks to manage and respond to runtime errors or exceptional events in a controlled manner, preventing program crashes.

questions.q: What is the `try` block in Java exception handling used for?
options: To define the code that handles an exception
To specify the code that should be executed regardless of whether an exception occurs
To enclose the code that might throw an exception
To declare a new exception type
questions.ex: The `try` block contains the code that is suspected to potentially throw an exception.

questions.q: What is the `catch` block in Java exception handling used for?
options: To enclose the code that might throw an exception
To specify the code that should be executed regardless of whether an exception occurs
To define the code that handles a specific type of exception
To declare a new exception type
questions.ex: The `catch` block is executed if an exception of the specified type occurs within the corresponding `try` block. It contains the code to handle the exception.

questions.q: What is the `finally` block in Java exception handling used for?
options: To enclose the code that might throw an exception
To define the code that handles an exception
To specify the code that should be executed regardless of whether an exception occurs (e.g., for cleanup)
To declare a new exception type
questions.ex: The `finally` block is optional and is executed after the `try` and `catch` blocks, regardless of whether an exception occurred or was caught. It is typically used for cleanup operations.

questions.q: What is the purpose of the `static` keyword in Java?
options: To indicate that a member belongs to an object
To indicate that a member belongs to the class itself, rather than to any specific instance (object) of the class
To restrict access to a member
questions.ex: The `static` keyword is used to declare class-level members. Static variables are shared among all instances of the class, and static methods can be called directly on the class without creating an object.

questions.q: What is the difference between an array and an ArrayList in Java?
options: Arrays are dynamic in size, ArrayLists are fixed size
Arrays can store objects, ArrayLists can only store primitive types
Arrays are fixed size and can store primitive types and objects, while ArrayLists are dynamic size and can only store objects (or wrappers for primitives)
questions.ex: Arrays have a fixed size determined at creation, while ArrayLists are part of the Collections framework and are dynamic in size. Arrays can store both primitive types and objects, while ArrayLists store objects (using wrapper classes for primitives).

questions.q: What is constructor chaining in Java?
options: Creating multiple constructors with different names
Calling a constructor from another constructor within the same class or from a subclass
Using multiple constructors to create a single object
Defining a constructor in an interface
questions.ex: Constructor chaining is the process of calling one constructor from another constructor. This can be done within the same class (using `this()`) or from a subclass to call a superclass constructor (using `super()`).

questions.q: What is the purpose of the `final` keyword in Java?
options: To indicate that a variable, method, or class cannot be changed or overridden
To indicate that a method returns no value
To make a member accessible from anywhere
questions.ex: The `final` keyword has different meanings depending on what it is applied to: a `final` variable is a constant, a `final` method cannot be overridden by subclasses, and a `final` class cannot be subclassed.

questions.q: What is the primary characteristic of Python?
questions.ex: Python is an interpreted language, meaning the code is executed line by line by an interpreter rather than being fully compiled before execution.

questions.q: Which of the following is NOT a standard data type in Python?
questions.ex: List, Tuple, and Set are built-in data types in Python. While Python has concepts related to arrays (like NumPy arrays), 'Array' itself is not a standard built-in data type in the same way.

questions.q: How do you assign a value to a variable in Python?
questions.ex: The `=` operator is used for assignment in Python, similar to many other programming languages.

questions.q: Which symbol is used for single-line comments in Python?
questions.ex: The `#` symbol is used to indicate a single-line comment in Python. Anything after `#` on that line is ignored by the interpreter.

questions.q: Which keyword is used to define a function in Python?
questions.ex: The `def` keyword is used to define a function in Python.

questions.q: What is the purpose of indentation in Python?
options: To make the code look pretty
To indicate blocks of code (like within loops, conditionals, and functions)
questions.ex: Indentation is crucial in Python. It is used to define the scope of blocks of code. Consistent indentation is required for the code to be syntactically correct.

questions.q: What is a list in Python?
options: An ordered collection of unique elements
An unordered collection of unique elements
An ordered, mutable collection of items
An unordered, immutable collection of key-value pairs
questions.ex: A list is a mutable (changeable), ordered sequence of elements. Lists are defined using square brackets `[]`.

questions.q: What is a tuple in Python?
options: An ordered, mutable collection of items
An ordered, immutable collection of items
An unordered collection of unique elements
An unordered, immutable collection of key-value pairs
questions.ex: A tuple is an immutable (unchangeable), ordered sequence of elements. Tuples are defined using parentheses `()`.

questions.q: What is a set in Python?
options: An ordered collection of unique elements
An unordered collection of unique elements
An ordered, mutable collection of items
An unordered, immutable collection of key-value pairs
questions.ex: A set is an unordered collection of unique elements. Sets are defined using curly braces `{}` or the `set()` constructor.

questions.q: What is a dictionary in Python?
options: An ordered collection of unique elements
An unordered collection of unique elements
An ordered, mutable collection of items
An unordered, mutable collection of key-value pairs
questions.ex: A dictionary is an unordered (in versions prior to Python 3.7, ordered in 3.7+), mutable collection of key-value pairs. Dictionaries are defined using curly braces `{}`.

questions.q: Which keyword is used to create a class in Python?
questions.ex: The `class` keyword is used to define a class in Python.

questions.q: What is the role of the `__init__` method in a Python class?
options: It is a constructor, automatically called when a new object is created to initialize its attributes
questions.ex: The `__init__` method is a special method in Python classes that serves as the constructor. It is called automatically when you create a new instance (object) of the class and is used to set up the initial state of the object.

questions.q: What is inheritance in Python?
options: Combining data and methods into a single unit
Having multiple methods with the same name but different parameters
A mechanism where a new class (subclass) derives properties and behaviors from an existing class (superclass)
Hiding the implementation details of a class
questions.ex: Inheritance allows a class (child class) to inherit attributes and methods from another class (parent class), promoting code reusability and establishing an 'is-a' relationship.

questions.q: What is polymorphism in Python?
options: A mechanism where a new class derives properties from an existing class
Combining data and methods into a single unit
Having multiple methods with the same name but different parameters
The ability of objects of different classes to respond to the same method call in their own way
questions.ex: Polymorphism in Python allows objects of different types to be treated uniformly when a method is called, as long as they support that method. This is often referred to as 'duck typing' ('If it walks like a duck and quacks like a duck, it's a duck').

questions.q: What is encapsulation in Python?
options: A mechanism where a new class derives properties from an existing class
Combining data and methods that operate on that data within a class
Having multiple methods with the same name but different parameters
The ability of objects of different classes to respond to the same method call
questions.ex: Encapsulation involves bundling data (attributes) and the methods that operate on that data within a class. While Python doesn't have strict access modifiers like `private`, encapsulation is achieved through conventions and property decorators.

questions.q: What is a module in Python?
options: A file containing Python code (definitions, statements, etc.) that can be imported and used in other Python programs
A variable that stores multiple values
questions.ex: A module is a Python file (`.py`) containing a collection of related functions, classes, and variables. Modules allow for code organization and reusability.

questions.q: How do you import a module named `math` in Python?
questions.ex: The `import` keyword is used to bring the definitions from a module into the current Python script or interactive session.

questions.q: What is the purpose of the `if`, `elif`, and `else` keywords in Python?
options: To implement conditional execution of code blocks
questions.ex: The `if`, `elif` (else if), and `else` keywords are used to create conditional statements, allowing the program to execute different code blocks based on whether certain conditions are true or false.

questions.q: What is the purpose of the `for` and `while` keywords in Python?
options: To implement loops for repeating code blocks
questions.ex: The `for` loop is typically used to iterate over a sequence (like a list or string), while the `while` loop repeats a block of code as long as a condition is true.

questions.q: What is slicing in Python?
options: Dividing a number by another number
Extracting a portion (substring, sublist, etc.) from a sequence (string, list, tuple)
questions.ex: Slicing allows you to access a range of elements from a sequence using indices and a colon notation (e.g., `my_list[start:end:step]`).

questions.q: What is the result of the expression `5 + 2 * 3` in Python?
questions.ex: Python follows the standard order of operations (PEMDAS/BODMAS). Multiplication (2 * 3 = 6) is performed before addition (5 + 6 = 11).

questions.q: What is the output of `print(type([]))` in Python?
questions.ex: The `type()` function returns the type of an object. `[]` creates an empty list, so its type is `list`.

questions.q: What is the output of `print('Hello' + ' ' + 'World')` in Python?
questions.ex: The `+` operator is used for string concatenation in Python, joining the strings together.

questions.q: How do you check if a key exists in a dictionary named `my_dict` in Python?
questions.ex: The `in` operator is the standard and most Pythonic way to check for the existence of a key in a dictionary.

questions.q: What is the purpose of the `range()` function in Python?
options: To create a list of numbers
To generate a sequence of numbers, often used in for loops
To calculate the range of values in a list
questions.ex: The `range()` function generates a sequence of numbers (an iterable). It is commonly used to control the number of iterations in a `for` loop.

questions.q: What is a docstring in Python?
options: A multi-line string used to document modules, classes, functions, or methods
questions.ex: Docstrings are special string literals used to document code in Python. They are enclosed in triple quotes (`'''Docstring'''` or `"""Docstring"""`) and can span multiple lines.

questions.q: What is the purpose of the `return` statement in a Python function?
options: To print output to the console
To stop the execution of the function and optionally send a value back to the caller
questions.ex: The `return` statement exits a function and optionally sends a value back to the part of the program that called the function.

questions.q: What is an exception in Python?
options: A syntax error in the code
An event that occurs during the execution of a program that disrupts the normal flow of instructions
A function that is called automatically
questions.ex: An exception is an error that occurs during the runtime of a program, causing the program to terminate abnormally if not handled.

questions.q: How do you handle exceptions in Python?
questions.ex: Python uses `try...except` blocks to handle exceptions. Code that might raise an exception is placed in the `try` block, and the code to handle the exception is placed in the `except` block. A `finally` block can be used for cleanup.

questions.q: What is the Python Package Index (PyPI)?
options: A website for learning Python basics
A repository of third-party Python software packages that can be easily installed
A tool for debugging Python code
questions.ex: PyPI (pronounced 'pie-pie') is the official third-party software repository for Python. It hosts thousands of libraries and frameworks that extend Python's capabilities.

questions.q: Which tool is commonly used to install packages from PyPI?
questions.ex: Pip is the standard package installer for Python. The command `pip install package_name` is used to download and install packages from PyPI.

questions.q: What is the primary purpose of a variable in programming?
options: To store a value that can change during program execution
questions.ex: Variables are named storage locations that hold data values which can be accessed and modified as the program runs.

questions.q: Which of the following best describes a data type?
options: A name given to a variable
The value stored in a variable
A classification of data which tells the compiler or interpreter how the programmer intends to use the data
questions.ex: A data type specifies the kind of data a variable can hold (e.g., integer, floating-point number, character, boolean) and the operations that can be performed on it.

questions.q: Which data type is used to store whole numbers (numbers without a fractional part)?
questions.ex: Integer data types are used to represent whole numbers, such as 5, -10, or 0.

questions.q: Which data type is used to store numbers with a fractional part?
questions.ex: Floating-point data types (like float or double) are used to represent numbers that have a decimal point, such as 3.14 or -0.5.

questions.q: Which data type is used to store true or false values?
questions.ex: Boolean data types can only hold one of two values: true or false, often used in conditional statements and logical operations.

questions.q: Which data type is used to store a sequence of characters (like words or sentences)?
questions.ex: String data types are used to represent text, consisting of a sequence of characters enclosed in quotes.

questions.q: What does an arithmetic operator like `+` or `-` perform?
questions.ex: Arithmetic operators are used for basic mathematical operations such as addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division.

questions.q: What does a relational operator like `>` or `<` perform?
questions.ex: Relational operators are used to compare two values and return a boolean result (true or false) based on the relationship between them.

questions.q: What does a logical operator like `AND` or `OR` perform?
questions.ex: Logical operators are used to combine or modify boolean expressions. `AND` returns true if both operands are true, `OR` returns true if at least one operand is true, and `NOT` negates a boolean value.

questions.q: What does the assignment operator `=` do?
options: Assigns the value on the right to the variable on the left
questions.ex: The assignment operator is used to store a value in a variable.

questions.q: Which operator is used to check if two values are equal?
questions.ex: The equality operator (`==`) is used to compare if two values are equal.

questions.q: Which operator is used to check if two values are NOT equal?
questions.ex: The not equal to operator (`!=`) is used to check if two values are not equal.

questions.q: What is operator precedence?
options: The order in which variables are declared
The order in which operators are evaluated in an expression
The order in which functions are called
The order in which data types are defined
questions.ex: Operator precedence determines the order in which operations are performed in an expression when multiple operators are present (e.g., multiplication and division are usually performed before addition and subtraction).

questions.q: What is operator associativity?
options: The direction (left-to-right or right-to-left) in which operators of the same precedence are evaluated
The order in which different types of operators are evaluated
The process of assigning values to variables
The combination of different data types
questions.ex: Operator associativity determines the grouping of operands when operators of the same precedence appear in an expression. For example, subtraction is left-associative (a - b - c is evaluated as (a - b) - c).

questions.q: What is a literal in programming?
options: A fixed value or constant that appears directly in the code
questions.ex: A literal is a way of representing a fixed value in the source code (e.g., `5` is an integer literal, `"Hello"` is a string literal, `True` is a boolean literal).

questions.q: Which of the following is a compound assignment operator?
questions.ex: Compound assignment operators combine an arithmetic or bitwise operation with an assignment (e.g., `a += 5` is equivalent to `a = a + 5`).

questions.q: What is type casting (or type conversion)?
options: Changing the value of a variable
Converting a value from one data type to another
questions.ex: Type casting is the process of explicitly converting a value of one data type into a value of another data type.

questions.q: In languages where integer division truncates the result, what is the result of 10 / 3?
questions.ex: In many programming languages (like C, C++, older Java), integer division discards the fractional part, resulting in a whole number.

questions.q: What is the modulo operator (`%`) used for?
options: Finding the remainder of a division
Finding the quotient of a division
questions.ex: The modulo operator returns the remainder when one number is divided by another.

questions.q: Which of the following is a logical NOT operator?
questions.ex: The logical NOT operator (`!` in many languages, `not` in Python) negates a boolean expression (true becomes false, false becomes true).

questions.q: What is a constant?
options: A variable whose value can change during program execution
A fixed value that cannot be changed during program execution
A function that returns a fixed value
questions.ex: A constant is a value that is fixed and does not change throughout the execution of a program. They are often declared using specific keywords (like `const` or `final`).

questions.q: Which programming paradigm focuses on using variables and functions to manipulate data?
questions.ex: Procedural programming is a paradigm based on the concept of the procedure call, where programs are organized into procedures or functions that operate on data stored in variables.

questions.q: What is the purpose of declaring a variable?
options: To assign a value to it
To reserve memory space for it and specify its data type (in some languages)
questions.ex: Declaring a variable typically involves informing the compiler or interpreter about the variable's name and often its data type so that memory can be allocated for it.

questions.q: In a statically typed language, when are data types checked?
questions.ex: In statically typed languages (like C++, Java), data types are checked at compile time. This helps catch type-related errors early in the development process.

questions.q: In a dynamically typed language, when are data types checked?
options: Only when a variable is declared
questions.ex: In dynamically typed languages (like Python, JavaScript), data types are checked at runtime. This allows for more flexibility but can lead to type-related errors during execution.

questions.q: What is implicit type conversion (coercion)?
options: Explicitly converting a value from one data type to another using a cast
Automatically converting a value from one data type to another by the compiler or interpreter during an operation
Changing the value of a variable
Declaring a variable with a specific data type
questions.ex: Implicit type conversion occurs automatically when an operation involves values of different data types, and the compiler or interpreter converts one type to another based on predefined rules.

questions.q: Which type of statement is used to execute a block of code only if a specified condition is true?
questions.ex: Conditional statements (like `if`) allow a program to make decisions and execute code based on whether a logical condition evaluates to true.

questions.q: Which keyword is used to introduce an 'else if' condition in many programming languages?
questions.ex: While the exact keyword varies by language, `elif` (or `else if`) is commonly used to specify an alternative condition to check if the initial `if` condition is false.

questions.q: Which block of code is executed if the condition in an `if` statement is false and there is no `elif` or `else`?
options: The block of code following the `if` block
No code inside the `if` block is executed
The code inside the `if` block is executed anyway
questions.ex: If the condition in an `if` statement is false and there is no `else` or `elif` block, the code inside the `if` block is simply skipped.

questions.q: What is the purpose of the `else` block in a conditional statement?
options: To specify a condition to be checked
To execute code when the `if` condition is true
To execute code when the `if` condition (and any `elif` conditions) are false
To repeat a block of code
questions.ex: The `else` block provides a default action to be taken when the condition(s) in the preceding `if` and `elif` statements are all false.

questions.q: Which type of loop is used to repeat a block of code a fixed number of times, often by iterating over a sequence?
questions.ex: For loops are commonly used for iterating over a known sequence of elements or for executing a block of code a predetermined number of times.

questions.q: Which type of loop continues to execute a block of code as long as a specified condition is true?
questions.ex: A while loop repeatedly executes its body as long as the boolean condition in the `while` clause remains true.

questions.q: Which type of loop executes the loop body at least once before checking the condition?
questions.ex: The do-while loop is an exit-controlled loop. The condition is checked after the loop body is executed, guaranteeing at least one iteration.

questions.q: What is an infinite loop?
options: A loop that executes a fixed number of times
A loop that terminates after a short time
A loop whose condition for termination is never met, causing it to run indefinitely
A loop that is nested within another loop
questions.ex: An infinite loop occurs when the loop's control condition never becomes false, causing the loop to execute continuously.

questions.q: What is the purpose of the `break` statement inside a loop?
options: To skip the current iteration and continue to the next
To restart the loop from the beginning
questions.ex: The `break` statement is used to terminate the execution of the innermost loop (or switch statement) and transfer control to the statement immediately following the loop.

questions.q: What is the purpose of the `continue` statement inside a loop?
options: To skip the rest of the current iteration and proceed to the next iteration of the loop
To restart the loop from the beginning
questions.ex: The `continue` statement skips the remaining code within the current iteration of a loop and moves to the next iteration.

questions.q: What is a nested loop?
options: A loop that executes a fixed number of times
A loop placed inside the body of another loop
A loop that only has one iteration
questions.ex: A nested loop is a loop that is contained within another loop. The inner loop executes completely for each iteration of the outer loop.

questions.q: In a `for` loop with a counter, which part is typically responsible for updating the counter?
questions.ex: The increment or decrement part of a `for` loop (often in the third expression of the loop header) is used to update the loop counter in each iteration.

questions.q: What is the main difference between a `while` loop and a `do-while` loop?
options: A `while` loop checks the condition before the first iteration, while a `do-while` loop checks it after the first iteration
A `while` loop executes at least once, while a `do-while` loop may not execute at all
A `while` loop is used for fixed iterations, while a `do-while` loop is used for indefinite iterations
questions.ex: The crucial difference is when the condition is evaluated. A `while` loop is entry-controlled, checking the condition at the beginning. A `do-while` loop is exit-controlled, checking the condition at the end, guaranteeing at least one execution of the loop body.

questions.q: What is a switch statement used for?
options: To repeat a block of code
To perform a series of conditional checks based on the value of a single variable or expression
questions.ex: A switch statement (or equivalent in some languages) provides a more concise way to handle multiple conditional branches based on matching the value of an expression against several possible constant values.

questions.q: In a switch statement, what is the purpose of the `case` keyword?
options: To specify a value to match against the switch expression
questions.ex: The `case` keyword is followed by a constant value. If the value of the switch expression matches a `case` value, the code block associated with that `case` is executed.

questions.q: In a switch statement, what is the purpose of the `default` keyword?
options: To specify a value to match
To execute code when none of the `case` values match the switch expression
questions.ex: The optional `default` block in a switch statement is executed if the value of the switch expression does not match any of the `case` values.

questions.q: In a switch statement, what is the purpose of the `break` keyword?
options: To continue to the next case
To exit the switch statement after a match is found and executed
questions.ex: The `break` statement within a `case` block is important to exit the switch statement after a match is found and executed, preventing 'fall-through' to subsequent cases.

questions.q: If you omit the `break` statement in a `case` block of a switch statement (in languages where this is allowed), what happens?
options: The program will produce an error
The code in the next `case` block will also be executed (fall-through)
The default case will be executed
questions.ex: In languages like C and C++, if a `break` statement is omitted from a `case`, execution will 'fall through' to the next `case` block (and subsequent ones) until a `break` or the end of the switch is encountered.

questions.q: Which control flow statement is used to make decisions in a program?
questions.ex: Conditional statements enable programs to execute different code paths based on specific conditions.

questions.q: Which control flow statement is used to repeat a set of instructions?
questions.ex: Iteration, typically implemented using loops (for, while, do-while), allows for the repeated execution of a block of code.

questions.q: What is the term for executing a set of instructions repeatedly?
questions.ex: Iteration is the process of repeating a block of code multiple times, which is the core concept behind loops.

questions.q: What is the term for choosing between different paths of execution based on a condition?
questions.ex: Selection (or decision making) involves choosing which block of code to execute based on whether a condition is true or false, implemented using conditional statements.

questions.q: Which type of loop is most suitable when you know exactly how many times you need to repeat a block of code?
questions.ex: For loops are generally preferred when the number of iterations is known in advance, such as iterating over the elements of a list or executing a block a fixed number of times using a counter.

questions.q: Which type of loop is most suitable when you need to repeat a block of code as long as a condition remains true, and the number of iterations is not known beforehand?
questions.ex: While loops are ideal when the number of iterations depends on a condition that changes during the loop's execution and is not fixed beforehand.

questions.q: In a `for` loop with initialization, condition, and increment (like in C++/Java), which part is evaluated first?
questions.ex: The initialization expression in a `for` loop is executed only once at the beginning of the loop.

questions.q: In a `for` loop with initialization, condition, and increment, when is the condition checked?
options: Only if the loop is nested
questions.ex: The condition in a `for` loop is checked before each iteration of the loop. If the condition is true, the loop body is executed; otherwise, the loop terminates.

questions.q: What is a function in programming?
options: A block of code that performs a specific task and can be reused
A statement that repeats a block of code
questions.ex: A function is a named, self-contained block of code designed to perform a specific task. Functions help in organizing code, making it more modular and reusable.

questions.q: What is the purpose of defining a function?
options: To make the program run faster
To reduce code redundancy and improve code organization
questions.ex: Defining functions allows you to group related code into reusable units, avoiding repetition and making the program easier to read, understand, and maintain.

questions.q: What is a function call?
options: Executing the code inside a function
Declaring a variable inside a function
questions.ex: A function call is the instruction to execute the code block defined by a function. When a function is called, the program's execution jumps to the function's code.

questions.q: What are parameters in a function definition?
options: The actual values passed to the function when it is called
Placeholder variables listed in the function definition that receive values when the function is called
The return value of the function
questions.ex: Parameters are variables listed in the function's signature (definition) that act as placeholders for the data that the function will receive when it is called.

questions.q: What are arguments in a function call?
options: The placeholder variables in the function definition
The actual values that are passed to the function when it is called
The return value of the function
questions.ex: Arguments are the actual values or expressions that are passed to a function when it is invoked (called). These values are assigned to the corresponding parameters in the function definition.

questions.q: What is the purpose of a `return` statement in a function?
options: To print output to the console
To exit the function and optionally send a value back to the caller
questions.ex: The `return` statement is used to terminate the execution of a function and send a value (the return value) back to the part of the program that called the function.

questions.q: What does a function that does not have a `return` statement (or returns implicitly) typically return in many languages?
questions.ex: Functions that don't explicitly return a value or have no `return` statement often implicitly return a specific value that indicates the absence of a meaningful return value (like `void` in C/C++, `None` in Python, `null` in Java).

questions.q: What is an array?
options: A single variable that stores a single value
A function that performs a specific task
A data structure that stores a collection of elements of the same data type in a fixed-size contiguous block of memory
questions.ex: An array is a fundamental data structure that allows you to store and access multiple elements of the same type using a single variable name and an index.

questions.q: How are individual elements in an array accessed?
options: Using the array name and the element's value
Using the array name and its data type
Using the array name and an index (position)
questions.ex: Elements in an array are accessed by providing the array name followed by the index (position) of the desired element within square brackets (e.g., `my_array[0]`).

questions.q: What is the index of the first element in most programming arrays?
questions.ex: Most programming languages use zero-based indexing for arrays, meaning the first element is at index 0, the second at index 1, and so on.

questions.q: What is a multi-dimensional array?
options: An array that can store elements of different data types
An array with a fixed size
An array of arrays (e.g., a 2D array representing a matrix)
An array that can grow or shrink in size
questions.ex: A multi-dimensional array is an array where each element is itself an array. A common example is a 2D array, which can be visualized as a table or matrix with rows and columns.

questions.q: How are elements in a 2D array typically accessed?
options: Using the array name and two indices (row and column)
Using the array name and the element's value
questions.ex: Elements in a 2D array are accessed using two indices: one for the row and one for the column (e.g., `my_2d_array[row_index][column_index]`).

questions.q: What is the process of passing a variable's value to a function called?
questions.ex: In pass by value, a copy of the argument's value is passed to the function. Changes made to the parameter inside the function do not affect the original variable outside the function.

questions.q: What is the process of passing a variable's memory address to a function called, allowing the function to modify the original variable?
questions.ex: In pass by reference (or pass by address/pointer), the memory address of the argument is passed to the function. This allows the function to directly access and modify the original variable.

questions.q: What is a function signature?
options: The name of the function only
The name of the function, its return type, and its parameter list
The value returned by the function
questions.ex: The function signature includes the function's name, the data type of the value it returns (if any), and the data types and order of its parameters.

questions.q: What is a pure function?
options: A function that does not return a value
A function that has no parameters
A function that always produces the same output for the same input and has no side effects (does not modify external state)
A function that is called only once
questions.ex: A pure function is a function that, given the same inputs, will always return the same output and will not cause any observable side effects (like modifying global variables or performing I/O).

questions.q: What is a side effect in the context of functions?
options: An error that occurs during function execution
An action performed by a function that affects the state of the program outside the function (e.g., modifying a global variable, printing to console, writing to a file)
The value returned by the function
An argument passed to the function
questions.ex: A side effect is any change in the program's state or observable behavior that occurs as a result of executing a function, other than returning a value.

questions.q: What is function overloading?
options: Defining multiple functions with different names but the same parameters
Defining multiple functions with the same name but different parameter lists (number, type, or order)
Defining a function within another function
Defining a function that calls itself
questions.ex: Function overloading allows you to create multiple functions with the same name in the same scope, as long as their parameter lists are unique, enabling the compiler to differentiate between them.

questions.q: What is recursion?
options: A function that does not return a value
A function that calls itself directly or indirectly to solve a problem
A function that has no parameters
A function that is called only once
questions.ex: Recursion is a programming technique where a function calls itself in order to solve a problem. It is often used for problems that can be broken down into smaller, self-similar subproblems.

questions.q: What is a base case in recursion?
options: The starting point of the recursion
The condition that stops the recursion and prevents infinite loops
The value returned by the recursive function
The parameters passed to the recursive function
questions.ex: A base case is a non-recursive condition within a recursive function that provides a stopping point, ensuring that the recursion eventually terminates.

questions.q: What is the typical benefit of using functions in a program?
questions.ex: Functions break down a program into smaller, manageable modules, making the code easier to understand, test, and debug, and promoting reusability.

questions.q: What is the purpose of a function prototype or declaration (in languages that require it)?
options: To inform the compiler about the function's name, return type, and parameters before its actual definition
To store the function's return value
questions.ex: A function prototype (or declaration) tells the compiler about a function's signature before the function's full definition appears in the code, allowing the compiler to check for correct usage of the function.

questions.q: What is the primary characteristic of an array that distinguishes it from other data structures like linked lists?
options: It stores elements of different data types
It stores elements in a contiguous block of memory, allowing for direct access using an index
It stores data in key-value pairs
questions.ex: Arrays provide direct access to elements using an index because the elements are stored in adjacent memory locations. Linked lists, on the other hand, require traversing the list to access elements.

questions.q: What is the term for the number of elements an array can hold?
questions.ex: The size or length of an array refers to the total number of elements it can store. In many languages, this size is fixed once the array is created.

questions.q: What is the concept of 'scope' in programming functions?
options: The range within the program where a variable or function is accessible and can be used
The return type of the function
questions.ex: Scope refers to the region of the code where an identifier (like a variable or function name) is valid and can be referenced. Variables declared within a function typically have local scope, meaning they are only accessible within that function.

questions.q: What is the fundamental building block of Object-Oriented Programming?
questions.ex: In OOP, everything is centered around objects, which are instances of classes.

questions.q: What is a class in OOP?
options: A blueprint or template for creating objects, defining their attributes and behaviors
A function that returns a value
A variable that stores multiple values
questions.ex: A class is a definition or blueprint that describes the properties (data) and behaviors (methods) that objects of that class will have.

questions.q: What is an object in OOP?
questions.ex: An object is a concrete realization or instance of a class. When you create an object, it occupies memory and has a specific state (values for its attributes).

questions.q: What is inheritance in OOP?
options: Combining data and methods into a single unit
The ability of an object to take on multiple forms
A mechanism where a new class (subclass) inherits properties and behaviors from an existing class (superclass)
Hiding the implementation details of a class
questions.ex: Inheritance allows a class to inherit (reuse) the attributes and methods of another class. This promotes code reusability and establishes an 'is-a' relationship between classes.

questions.q: What is polymorphism in OOP?
options: A mechanism where a new class inherits properties from an existing class
Combining data and methods into a single unit
The ability of an object or method to take on multiple forms or have multiple implementations
Hiding the implementation details of a class
questions.ex: Polymorphism allows objects of different classes to be treated as objects of a common superclass, and a single method call can result in different behaviors depending on the object's actual type.

questions.q: What is encapsulation in OOP?
options: A mechanism where a new class inherits properties from an existing class
Combining data (attributes) and the methods that operate on that data within a single unit (a class), and often restricting direct access to the data
Having multiple methods with the same name but different parameters
The ability of an object to take on multiple forms
questions.ex: Encapsulation is the bundling of data and methods within a class. It helps protect the internal state of an object and control access to its data, often through getters and setters.

questions.q: What is abstraction in OOP?
options: Focusing on the implementation details of a class
Hiding complex details and showing only essential features or relevant information to the user
Repeating a block of code multiple times
questions.ex: Abstraction is the process of simplifying complex reality by modeling classes based on essential properties and behaviors, hiding the underlying implementation details.

questions.q: In OOP, what is an attribute?
options: A behavior or action that an object can perform
A property or characteristic of an object
A function that belongs to a class
questions.ex: Attributes are the data members or properties that define the state of an object (e.g., color, size, name).

questions.q: In OOP, what is a method?
options: A property or characteristic of an object
A behavior or action that an object can perform; a function associated with a class or object
A variable that stores a value
questions.ex: Methods are the functions that belong to a class or object. They define the behaviors that an object can perform or the operations that can be done on its data.

questions.q: What is a constructor in OOP?
options: A method that is automatically called when an object is destroyed
A method that is automatically called when an object is created to initialize its attributes
A method that returns a value
questions.ex: A constructor is a special method within a class that is invoked automatically when a new object of that class is created. Its primary purpose is to initialize the object's attributes.

questions.q: What is a destructor in OOP (in languages that support it)?
options: A method that is automatically called when an object is created
A method that is automatically called when an object is destroyed to clean up resources
A method that returns a value
questions.ex: A destructor is a special method that is called automatically when an object is destroyed (e.g., when it goes out of scope or is explicitly deleted). It is used to release resources held by the object, such as allocated memory.

questions.q: Which OOP principle is demonstrated by having multiple functions with the same name but different parameter lists?
questions.ex: Function or method overloading, where multiple functions/methods share the same name but differ in their parameters, is a form of polymorphism (specifically, ad-hoc or compile-time polymorphism).

questions.q: Which OOP principle is demonstrated by being able to treat objects of different subclasses uniformly through a reference or pointer to their common superclass?
questions.ex: Subtype polymorphism (or runtime polymorphism) allows you to use a base class pointer or reference to refer to objects of derived classes. The actual method that gets called is determined at runtime based on the object's actual type.

questions.q: What is the relationship between a class and an object?
options: An object is a blueprint for a class
A class is an instance of an object
An object is an instance of a class
questions.ex: A class is the definition or template, while an object is a concrete instance created from that template.

questions.q: Which of the following is NOT a core principle of Object-Oriented Programming?
questions.ex: Inheritance, Polymorphism, Encapsulation, and Abstraction are the four main pillars of OOP. Normalization is a concept related to database design.

questions.q: What is the primary benefit of using encapsulation?
options: To allow direct access to all data
To hide implementation details and protect data integrity
To create new classes based on existing ones
To enable objects to take on multiple forms
questions.ex: Encapsulation helps in data hiding, controlling how the internal state of an object can be accessed and modified, thereby protecting data integrity and allowing for easier maintenance and modification of the class's implementation without affecting other parts of the code.

questions.q: What is the primary benefit of using inheritance?
options: To promote code reusability and establish a hierarchy of classes
questions.ex: Inheritance allows subclasses to reuse the code (attributes and methods) defined in their superclass, reducing redundancy and making the codebase more organized.

questions.q: What is the primary benefit of using polymorphism?
options: To write more flexible and extensible code that can work with objects of different types through a common interface
To limit the number of classes
questions.ex: Polymorphism enables writing code that can operate on objects of different types in a uniform way, making the code more adaptable to new classes or types without requiring significant modifications.

questions.q: What is the primary benefit of using abstraction?
options: To simplify complex systems by focusing on essential features and hiding unnecessary complexity
To make code harder to understand
To prevent the creation of objects
questions.ex: Abstraction helps in managing complexity by providing a high-level view of an object or system, allowing developers to focus on what it does rather than how it does it.

questions.q: What is the 'is-a' relationship in OOP typically represented by?
questions.ex: Inheritance represents an 'is-a' relationship (e.g., a 'Car' is a 'Vehicle'). A subclass is a specialized type of its superclass.

questions.q: What is the 'has-a' relationship in OOP typically represented by?
questions.ex: The 'has-a' relationship (or composition/aggregation) represents that an object contains or is composed of other objects (e.g., a 'Car' has an 'Engine'). This is typically implemented by having instances of other classes as attributes within a class.

questions.q: What is a static member of a class?
options: A member that belongs to a specific object instance
A member that belongs to the class itself, rather than to any specific instance, and is shared among all instances
A member that can only be accessed from outside the class
questions.ex: Static members (variables or methods) are associated with the class as a whole, not with individual objects. There is only one copy of a static variable shared by all objects of the class.

questions.q: What is method overriding?
options: Defining multiple methods with the same name in the same class
Defining a method in a subclass with the same name and signature as a method in its superclass
Calling a method from another method in the same class
Defining a method that is only accessible within the class
questions.ex: Method overriding occurs when a subclass provides a specific implementation for a method that is already defined in its superclass. The method in the subclass has the same name, return type, and parameter list as the one in the superclass.

questions.q: What is an interface in OOP (in languages that support it)?
options: A class that cannot be instantiated
A blueprint of a class, containing abstract methods and constants, that a class can implement
questions.ex: An interface defines a contract specifying a set of methods that implementing classes must provide. It enforces a standard way of interacting with objects of different classes that implement the same interface.

questions.q: What is the primary difference between an abstract class and an interface (in languages like Java)?
options: Abstract classes can have both abstract and concrete methods and member variables, while interfaces primarily contain abstract methods and constants
Abstract classes can be instantiated, while interfaces cannot
Abstract classes can only be inherited, while interfaces can be both inherited and implemented
questions.ex: Abstract classes can have a mix of implemented methods and abstract methods, and can have member variables. Interfaces, in their traditional form, only contain abstract methods and constants (though newer Java versions allow default and static methods in interfaces).

questions.q: What does HTML stand for?
questions.ex: HTML is the standard markup language used to create and structure content on the World Wide Web.

questions.q: What does CSS stand for?
questions.ex: CSS is a style sheet language used for describing the presentation of a document written in HTML (or XML).

questions.q: Which HTML tag is used to define the structure of an HTML document, including the `head` and `body` sections?
questions.ex: The `<html>` element is the root element of an HTML page.

questions.q: Which HTML tag is used to define the content that is displayed in the browser window?
questions.ex: The `<body>` element contains all the visible content of an HTML document, such as text, images, links, and more.

questions.q: Which HTML tag is used to define information about the HTML document, such as its title, character set, and links to external resources?
questions.ex: The `<head>` element contains meta-information about the HTML document, which is not directly displayed on the page.

questions.q: Which HTML tag is used to create a hyperlink?
questions.ex: The `<a>` tag (anchor tag) is used to create hyperlinks to other web pages, files, or locations within the same page.

questions.q: Which HTML attribute is used to specify the URL of the page the link goes to?
questions.ex: The `href` attribute specifies the destination of a hyperlink.

questions.q: Which HTML tag is used to embed an image in an HTML page?
questions.ex: The `` tag is used to insert images into an HTML document.

questions.q: Which HTML attribute is used to specify the URL of the image file?
questions.ex: The `src` attribute specifies the path to the image file that the `` tag should display.

questions.q: How do you apply an external CSS stylesheet to an HTML document?
options: Using the `<style>` tag in the body
Using the `<link>` tag in the head
Using inline styles in HTML elements
questions.ex: The `<link>` tag with the `rel="stylesheet"` attribute placed within the `<head>` section of the HTML document is the standard way to link an external CSS file.

questions.q: Which CSS property is used to change the text color of an element?
questions.ex: The `color` property in CSS is used to set the color of the text content of an element.

questions.q: Which CSS property is used to change the background color of an element?
questions.ex: The `background-color` property sets the background color of an element.

questions.q: Which CSS property is used to control the spacing between the content and the border of an element?
questions.ex: Padding is the space between the content of an element and its border.

questions.q: Which CSS property is used to control the spacing outside the border of an element?
questions.ex: Margin is the space around an element, outside of its border.

questions.q: What is the CSS Box Model?
options: A model for structuring HTML documents
A model that describes how HTML elements are displayed as rectangular boxes with properties like content, padding, border, and margin
A model for organizing CSS rules
A model for creating responsive layouts
questions.ex: The CSS Box Model describes the components of a box (element) in CSS: content, padding, border, and margin. Understanding the box model is crucial for controlling spacing and layout.

questions.q: Which CSS selector is used to select elements with a specific id?
questions.ex: The `#` symbol is used in CSS to select an element by its unique `id` attribute.

questions.q: Which CSS selector is used to select elements with a specific class?
questions.ex: The `.` symbol is used in CSS to select elements that have a specific class name.

questions.q: What is the difference between an id selector and a class selector in CSS?
options: An id selector selects multiple elements, while a class selector selects a single element
An id should be unique within an HTML document, while a class can be used on multiple elements
An id is used for styling, while a class is used for functionality
questions.ex: The `id` attribute should be unique within an HTML document and is used to identify a single element. The `class` attribute can be applied to multiple elements, allowing you to apply the same styles to several elements.

questions.q: Which CSS property is used to change the font size of text?
questions.ex: The `font-size` property sets the size of the text.

questions.q: Which CSS property is used to make text bold?
questions.ex: The `font-weight` property is used to set the thickness of the characters in text. A value like `bold` or a numerical value like `700` makes the text bold.

questions.q: Which CSS property is used to change the font family of text?
questions.ex: The `font-family` property specifies the font to be used for text.

questions.q: What is the purpose of the `alt` attribute in the `` tag?
options: To specify the alignment of the image
To provide alternative text for the image if it cannot be displayed (important for accessibility and SEO)
To set the width and height of the image
To add a caption to the image
questions.ex: The `alt` attribute provides a text description of the image. This text is displayed if the image fails to load or is being viewed by a screen reader for visually impaired users.

questions.q: Which HTML tag is used to create an ordered list?
questions.ex: The `<ol>` tag is used to create an ordered list, where list items are typically numbered.

questions.q: Which HTML tag is used to create an unordered list?
questions.ex: The `<ul>` tag is used to create an unordered list, where list items are typically marked with bullet points.

questions.q: Which HTML tag is used to define a list item within an ordered or unordered list?
questions.ex: The `<li>` tag is used to define each individual item within an ordered or unordered list.

questions.q: What is semantic HTML?
options: HTML that uses meaningful tags to describe the content's purpose and structure, improving accessibility and SEO
HTML that is difficult to read
questions.ex: Semantic HTML uses tags like `<article>`, `<nav>`, `<aside>`, `<header>`, `<footer>`, etc., to convey the meaning and structure of the content, rather than just its presentation.

questions.q: What is the purpose of the `<head>` section in an HTML document?
options: To contain the main content of the page
To contain meta-information about the document, links to stylesheets, and scripts
To define the page header visually
questions.ex: The `<head>` section holds information that is not displayed directly to the user but is important for the browser, search engines, and linking external resources.

questions.q: Which CSS property is used to add a border around an element?
questions.ex: The `border` property allows you to set the width, style, and color of an element's border.

questions.q: What is the default value of the `position` property in CSS?
questions.ex: The default value of the `position` property is `static`, meaning the element is positioned according to the normal flow of the document.

questions.q: Which CSS property is used to hide an element?
options: All of the above can hide an element, but in different ways.
questions.ex: `visibility: hidden;` makes the element invisible but it still occupies space. `display: none;` completely removes the element from the document flow. `opacity: 0;` makes the element completely transparent but it still occupies space and is interactive.

questions.q: What is the purpose of media queries in CSS?
options: To apply styles only to specific types of media (e.g., print, screen)
questions.ex: Media queries are used to apply different styles based on the characteristics of the device displaying the document, such as screen size, resolution, and orientation. This is essential for responsive web design.

questions.q: Which CSS property is used to control the order of flexible items in a flex container?
questions.ex: The `order` property is applied to individual flex items and allows you to change their visual order within the flex container, regardless of their order in the HTML source.

questions.q: Which CSS property is used to align flexible items along the main axis of a flex container?
questions.ex: The `justify-content` property aligns flex items along the flex container's main axis. Common values include `flex-start`, `flex-end`, `center`, `space-between`, and `space-around`.

questions.q: Which CSS property is used to align flexible items along the cross axis of a flex container?
questions.ex: The `align-items` property aligns flex items along the flex container's cross axis. Common values include `flex-start`, `flex-end`, `center`, `stretch`, and `baseline`.

questions.q: Which HTML tag is used to create a table?
questions.ex: The `<table>` tag is used to define an HTML table. It contains table rows (`<tr>`), table data cells (`<td>`), and table header cells (`<th>`).

questions.q: Which HTML tag represents a row in a table?
questions.ex: The `<tr>` tag defines a row in an HTML table.

questions.q: Which HTML tag represents a standard data cell in a table?
questions.ex: The `<td>` tag defines a standard data cell in an HTML table.

questions.q: Which HTML tag represents a header cell in a table?
questions.ex: The `<th>` tag defines a header cell in an HTML table. Header cells are often displayed in bold and centered.

questions.q: What is the purpose of the `colspan` attribute in a table cell?
options: To set the width of a column
To set the height of a row
questions.ex: The `colspan` attribute is used in `<td>` or `<th>` tags to merge a cell across multiple columns.

questions.q: What is the purpose of the `rowspan` attribute in a table cell?
options: To set the width of a column
To set the height of a row
questions.ex: The `rowspan` attribute is used in `<td>` or `<th>` tags to merge a cell across multiple rows.

questions.q: What is the difference between `display: block;` and `display: inline;` in CSS?
options: `block` elements start on a new line and take up the full width available, while `inline` elements do not start on a new line and only take up as much width as necessary.
`inline` elements start on a new line, while `block` elements do not.
`block` elements cannot have margin or padding, while `inline` elements can.

questions.q: What is JavaScript primarily used for?
options: Adding interactivity and dynamic behavior to web pages
questions.ex: JavaScript is a scripting language that enables you to create dynamically updating content, control multimedia, animate images, and pretty much everything else on a web page.

questions.q: Which tag is used to link an external JavaScript file to an HTML document?
questions.ex: The `<script>` tag is used to embed or reference executable code on an HTML page. The `src` attribute specifies the URL of the external script file.

questions.q: Which keyword is used to declare a variable in modern JavaScript (ES6+)?
questions.ex: Modern JavaScript (ES6 and later) introduced `let` and `const` as preferred alternatives to `var`. `let` is used for variables that can be reassigned, and `const` is used for variables that cannot be reassigned (though the value of an object or array declared with `const` can still be modified).

questions.q: Which JavaScript keyword is used to declare a variable whose value cannot be reassigned?
questions.ex: The `const` keyword declares variables that are block-scoped and whose value cannot be reassigned once initialized. Note that for objects and arrays, this prevents reassigning the variable itself, but the contents of the object or array can still be modified.

questions.q: Which JavaScript keyword is used to declare a variable that is block-scoped and can be reassigned?
questions.ex: The `let` keyword declares variables that are block-scoped and can be reassigned. It is generally preferred over `var` in modern JavaScript.

questions.q: What is the data type of `null` in JavaScript?
questions.ex: Despite representing an intentional absence of any object value, `typeof null` in JavaScript returns 'object'. This is considered a historical bug in the language.

questions.q: What is the data type of `undefined` in JavaScript?
questions.ex: The `undefined` data type represents a variable that has been declared but has not yet been assigned a value.

questions.q: Which operator is used to check if two values are equal in both value and data type?
questions.ex: The strict equality operator (`===`) checks if two values are equal without performing type coercion (conversion). Both the value and the data type must be the same for it to return `true`.

questions.q: Which operator is used to check if two values are equal in value, allowing for type coercion?
questions.ex: The equality operator (`==`) compares two values for equality. It performs type coercion if the operands are of different types before making the comparison.

questions.q: How do you write an `if` statement in JavaScript?
questions.ex: The standard syntax for an `if` statement in JavaScript is `if (condition) { // code }`.

questions.q: How do you write a `for` loop that iterates from 0 to 4 (inclusive)?
questions.ex: The `for` loop syntax typically includes initialization, condition, and increment/decrement. To iterate from 0 up to (but not including) 5, the condition is `i < 5`. If you wanted inclusive, you would use `i <= 4`.

questions.q: How do you write a `while` loop that continues as long as a variable `count` is less than 10?
questions.ex: The `while` loop syntax in JavaScript is `while (condition) { // code }`.

questions.q: What is a function in JavaScript?
options: A block of code that performs a specific task and can be reused
A statement that repeats a block of code
questions.ex: Functions in JavaScript are first-class citizens, meaning they can be assigned to variables, passed as arguments, and returned from other functions. They encapsulate reusable code blocks.

questions.q: How do you define a function named `greet` that takes no parameters?
options: Both A and C are valid ways.
questions.ex: Both the `function` keyword declaration and assigning an anonymous function to a variable are common ways to define functions in JavaScript.

questions.q: What is the purpose of the `return` statement in a JavaScript function?
options: To print output to the console
To stop the execution of the function and optionally send a value back to the caller
